HEADLINE: To Close the Income Gap 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 An April 24 news article notes that growth in income inequality over the last several decades was particularly pronounced in New York State. 
 The 1990's were a boom time for the state on average, but the prosperity was not broadly shared, and New York's income gaps continued to grow. 
These findings should serve as a wake-up call for New York policy makers. Religious, labor, civic, government and business leaders should convene a series of summit meetings to address both the causes and the consequences of this situation and to develop a strategic plan for reducing child poverty, increasing job opportunities and ensuring that the incomes of working families do not continue to deteriorate. 

TRUDI RENWICK
Latham, N.Y., April 25, 2002

The writer is a senior economist, Fiscal Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Japan's Central Bank Paints A Brighter Economic Picture 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 30 

 BODY:
Mirroring the growing view that Japan will emerge from recession later this year, the Bank of Japan upgraded its economic forecasts today in one of its twice-yearly reviews. But it gave no sign of abandoning its ultraloose monetary policy, with short-term interest rates effectively at zero.
 The central bank said today that it now expected Japan's $4.1 trillion economy, the second-largest after the United States, to contract by about 0.5 percent in the fiscal year that began April 1. It had previously predicted a 1 percent contraction. 
 The bank also saw chinks of light in the heavy overcast of deflation, which has plagued the country and undermined revival efforts in recent years. The bank's policy board said that even though wholesale and consumer prices would fall this year, they would do so more gradually. 
The policy board, which left monetary policy unchanged at its meeting today, said that Japanese exports and industrial production were picking up, and with them the outlook for corporate profits. But growing competition and the costs of writing off bad loans will continue to depress job creation, wages and prices, limiting consumer spending and any chance for a full-blown recovery.
Japan's economy is expected to stop deteriorating toward the latter half of the fiscal year and turn upward again, though it is not likely to gain much upward momentum, the bank said.
Delays in disposing of nonperforming loans will hamstring the economy, the central bank said. The country's commercial banks have been curtailing their lending despite vanishingly low interest rates because they are reluctant to take on new risks. This caution has stunted investment and growth, the bank said.
Still, with the economy now out of any immediate danger of collapse -- and with a few private economists even predicting modest growth this year -- the bank is unlikely to repeat its performance of the last year, when it eased monetary policy, one way or another, seven times. The central bank is more likely to take small incremental steps, like increasing the amount of money it leaves in the markets overnight, rather than turning to unconventional measures like huge purchases of foreign bonds, analysts said.
"Because of the cyclical recovery," said Mikihiro Matsuoka, an economist at Deutsche Securities in Tokyo, "the bank can make some excuse of not loosening policy like in the past." 
Signs of that recovery, driven largely by increasing demand overseas, were visible on Monday, when the government reported a 0.5 percent month-to-month gain in industrial output in March. Output also rose 1.2 percent in February. The economy had not posted consecutive monthly gains in almost two years.
But new statistics today showed that domestic demand remained anemic. Construction orders for March were 12.9 percent lower than in March 2001, and housing starts fell 6.3 percent from a year ago. And crude oil imports -- Japan must import nearly all of its energy -- were down 6.4 percent from a year before.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Downtown Dallas Project Mired in Disputes

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Thomas O. Hicks fiddles with a gold ring with a big star on it, smiling only when he can change the subject from the controversies over the proposed 20-acre development next to the arena used by one of the sports franchises he owns to the fortunes of the teams themselves.
 The Stars of hockey missed the playoffs for the first time in six seasons, and the Rangers have no pitching to speak of, but he would rather talk about them than about his development's critics in the Dallas City Council. 
 Mr. Hicks is a partner in a plan to develop a timeworn swath of land into an architecturally distinguished combination of upscale shops, office buildings and hotels between the new arena where his Stars play and the heart of downtown Dallas. The proposal is called Victory, but Mr. Hicks, a partner in the leveraged buyout firm of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, says he is losing his taste for the fight. To try to sink financing plans crucial to the mixed-use project, he says, the Victory development's opponents are using arguments that failed in a 1998 referendum that provided financing for the arena. 
"It's silly," he said. "You've got a $600 million development fully funded in a recession. We've got political opportunists trying to refight the 1998 election. It's over. We won."
Some opponents of his project are politicians, but others are fellow developers, property owners just across the highway in the central business district. The 1998 election he spoke of was a bond referendum in which the city took on $125 million in debt to finance the sports arena proposed by Mr. Hicks and by his partner in both the arena and the Victory project, H. Ross Perot Jr. Since then, the city has authorized other spending for the area around the Victory project, and critics of Mr. Hicks and his partners argue that the shovels should be in the ground.
"How much is enough?" asked Laura Miller, the new mayor of Dallas, in an interview at City Hall. "Is $167 million in taxes enough for the developer to go out and develop now? Baby needs to walk now."
The story of Victory begins, or rather picks up, after Dallas voters narrowly approved the bond sale to help finance the American Airlines Center as the new home for the hockey Stars and for the basketball Mavericks, which Mr. Perot owned at the time. To repay the debt, the city raised rental car and hotel taxes. 
That done, the city created a tax- increment-financing district to pay for roads and plazas around the new arena. The developers were to spend $24.9 million, and they were to be reimbursed, plus interest of about 6 percent compounded semiannually, from new city property tax revenues created by the escalating value of the land. So far, the property value has risen 135 percent, and by May 15 the city will have collected about $575,000 in new tax revenue to pay the developers.
The agreement also called for mixed-use development nearby, but it was not specific.
Mr. Perot, the son of the computing pioneer and former presidential candidate, then made a $155 million profit by selling the basketball team to the Internet entrepreneur Mark Cuban. But Mr. Perot had bigger plans. He was buying up the land between the arena and the central business district, where he spent about $12 million stripping out oil and carcinogenic ash. He won an award from the Environmental Protection Agency.
"We picked that area north of the West End because it was the last blighted area," Mr. Perot said in a telephone interview. "It was an area where you could have a big impact."
By 1999, Mr. Perot and some minority partners owned 60 acres, and they sold 43 percent of that to Mr. Hicks for about $30 million. They brought in the Palladium Company, a developer known for the 72-acre mixed-use complex called CityPlace in West Palm Beach, as well as for its partnership with Apollo Real Estate Advisers and the Related Companies in building the AOL Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle in Manhattan.
Mr. Hicks and Mr. Perot and their partners secured more than $100 million in equity financing from California Urban Investment Partners, a joint venture between MacFarlane Partners and the California Public Employees Retirement System.
And they asked the city to sell new bonds worth $83 million, creating debt service payments of about $175 million over 30 years. In return, the city would get an urban oasis that the partners likened to Rockefeller Center, built with the public funds and with $550 million in private money. The stroll from the American Airlines Center to the central business district would be a tree-lined affair, spotted with gathering spaces and lined with 500,000 square feet of retail space, a 40-story office tower, two hotels and hundreds of apartments.
There was an outcry. Downtown property owners with their own proposals for revitalization, including the Trammel Crow Company and Crescent Real Estate Equities, wrote to urge the City Council not to adopt the plan. 
So the land adjacent to American Airlines Center sits there, host to a half-demolished power plant and a small Victory marketing office. Palladium has presented a new plan, for $31 million to $33 million in bond financing. It has said it will pay for the streets upfront, and it has given up all manner of earlier financing proposals, including expanding the tax-increment-financing district and extending its life.
Mr. Hicks has announced that he will sell his stake in the project if doing so would clear the political opposition, but he quickly conceded in an interview that this proposal was, itself, little more than an attempt "to frame public debate about the issues." There is, after all, little reason for anyone to buy the land unless approval of the development project is assured.
Under the new proposal, Mr. Hicks and Mr. Perot would still sell their property to Palladium, retaining small equity stakes in the development. Mr. Perot said he would take a loss on the land. They would still own the 40 acres between the edge of the proposed development and downtown, inside the financing district where land values would be expected to rise markedly. The city has commissioned more studies and scheduled more public hearings.
"The issue is not whether you're for it or against it, it's how will it be funded," said Steven D. Wolens, who is involved in the Victory proposal every way but directly. Mr. Wolens is a Democratic state representative whose district includes part of downtown Dallas. He also sponsored the state legislation allowing cities to create tax-increment-financing districts. And he is married to the mayor.
So far, Dallas has embraced the notion that financing downtown development will increase property values, attract new business and increase tax revenue all over town. But the city benefited greatly from the 10-year national economic expansion, and office vacancy rates downtown never dropped below 20 percent.
Part of the controversy surrounding the Victory proposal is about the use of tax increment financing to promote the development of downtown.
With the Victory proposal, "we're rearranging economic activity within the metropolitan area," said Lori L. Taylor, a senior economic policy adviser at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. "If you're looking at the broader metro area, it's a bit of robbing Peter to pay Paul."
Beyond the competing development proposals, Mayor Miller's own plans indicate a broader shift for the city's financial priorities. The city has already identified $1 billion or more in roadway improvements it wants to make, and has scheduled a $200 million bond referendum based on a conservative estimate that includes not raising taxes. It has pledged to raise the pay of all public safety workers, not just the police.
"In terms of maintaining the city's triple-A rating, we want to see those kinds of projects addressed," said Alex Fraser, a municipal bond analyst for Standard & Poor's. "That's really more important than the Victory development. If anything, that project could provide some interference."
Mr. Perot remains energized.
"These things are always a challenge," he said. "But the City Council understands the challenge."

PERSON: Dr. Gordon Randolph Willey 

HEADLINE: Gordon R. Willey, 89, Archaeologist Who Broadened Studies 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Gordon Randolph Willey, a Harvard archaeologist who broadened the study of vanished societies from the examination of the tombs of the elite to include the economic and social lives of ordinary people, died on Sunday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89. 
 A prolific scholar of pre-Columbian America, Dr. Willey pioneered what is known as settlement pattern studies, an approach he applied methodically in the Viru Valley on the northern coast of Peru in the 1940's. 
 He investigated the artifacts of households and public works to open a new window on a society of long ago. The remains of its ancient settlements, he found, reflected their inhabitants' use of their environment and their relations with their neighbors.
That, in turn, permitted the anthropologists of today to reconstruct the economic, political and social organization of ancient peoples.
Dr. Willey, who was at Harvard for 36 years, distinguished himself with meticulously documented research at Maya archaeological sites in Belize, Guatemala and Honduras. He made substantive and theoretical contributions to the archaeology of the Americas and to comparative studies with the old civilizations of other continents.
Before setting his sights on the Viru Valley, he reported important findings about the history of the Southeastern United States, using innovative methods to analyze pottery and reconstruct ancient cultures.
Born in Chariton, Iowa, Gordon Willey graduated in 1935 from the University of Arizona and was selected for Phi Beta Kappa. He received a master's from Arizona the next year and a Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1942. 
Early in his career he worked for the Smithsonian.
His book "Archeology of the Florida Gulf Coast" (1949), became an instant classic and remains in the backpacks of archaeologists working there. A reprint edition is now available.
More than a dozen of Dr. Willey's books and monographs are still in print. Their topics include excavations at Seibal, Guatemala; the archaeology of Southern Mesoamerica; and the early classic period in the Maya Lowlands.
With Jeremy A. Sabloff he wrote "A History of American Archeology," which scholars consider a major work in the field, defending his settlement pattern approach to excavations. Its third edition was issued in 1993 and remains in print. Some of his writing was devoted to archaeological mystery novels, the first of which, "Selena," was republished by Harlequin Books in 1995.
Dr. Willey was named Harvard's first Charles P. Bowditch professor of Central American and Mexican archaeology in 1950. He served as department chairman later in the 1950's, became Bowditch professor emeritus in 1984 but continued as a senior professor of anthropology until 1987.
He was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences, and he was a past president of the American Archaeological Society.
Dr. Willey is survived by two daughters, Alexandra Gurelnick and Winston Adler, and five grandchildren. His wife, Katharine Whaley Willey, died last year after 63 years of marriage.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Slipped During April 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence fell during April, a private research group reported today, as higher energy prices and a declining stock market tempered optimism about economic growth.
 The Conference Board's gauge of sentiment dropped to 108.8 this month from 110.7 in March. 
The drop was less than expected. 
 Manufacturing in the Chicago region grew in April for a third consecutive month, according to a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago. While the group's factory index dropped to 54.7 from 55.7, any reading above 50 indicates expansion.
The regional report supports economists' expectations that a survey Wednesday will show that manufacturing expanded nationwide in April for a third month.
While the confidence index fell this month, it has rebounded since late last year, when the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 brought the economy to a standstill. The outlook for six months from now remained at a level seen before the recession. And optimism about job prospects increased.

HEADLINE: Faraway School Close to Mount Vernon Woman 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: CHESTER, S.C. 

 BODY:
Vivian Ayers lives in Mount Vernon, N.Y., but closest to her heart is a boarding school nearly 700 miles away, here in South Carolina. 
 The Brainerd Institute, which opened in 1866 for the children of freed slaves, was the only high school for black students in Chester County, South Carolina, well into the 1920's. Ms. Ayers, who grew up in a house across the street from the school, was a member of its last graduating class. The school closed in 1939 as local government began providing more high schools for black students. 
 All that remains of the institute is a boarded-up brick building, once a dormitory known as Kumler Hall. But Ms. Ayers has been working for three years to restore the building, not only to preserve the history of a school that helped shape her but also to commemorate the long struggle of black Americans to provide their children with a good education. She and other supporters of the preservation effort are mindful that the school was a consequence of segregation, but they say the institute needs to be remembered because it rose above the mediocrity of many schools to produce doctors, ministers and schoolteachers. 
Ms. Ayers wants to establish a research and tourist center that would study and memorialize those achievements. She cites Stratford-upon-Avon as her model: an economic engine fueled by concentration on all things Shakespeare. "Brainerd can do even more if we can regenerate it," she said. 
Ms. Ayers, a stylish woman with a lively laugh, is in a distinctive position to make the project happen. She has enlisted her daughters, the actress Phylicia Rashad and the choreographer and director Debbie Allen, as well as architects, builders and the Chester Historical Society in the mission Ms. Ayers says she was born to lead. When it seemed a developer might build apartments on the school's land in 1998, Ms. Rashad -- who played Clair Huxtable, lawyer, to Bill Cosby's Dr. Heathcliff Huxtable on the landmark television show -- bought the 12-acre property for $115,000 and turned it over to her mother. "She wrote a check, just like that, and solved the crisis," Ms. Ayers said. 
Ms. Rashad, along with her sister, Ms. Allen, had performed in Chester in an earlier effort to raise money to restore Kumler Hall. Ms. Rashad bought the school property, she said, "because my mother wanted me to." 
"When you think of the things you could give a person, most of those would not mean much to her," Ms. Rashad said. "But this meant everything to her." 
For the first two years of Brainerd's existence -- part of the post-Civil War Freedmen's Bureau -- two women, E. E. Richmond from New York and Carolyn I. Kent from New Jersey, ran the school. In 1869 the school was taken over by the Presbyterian Church. 
Until 1928 the school's leadership was white but black teachers and administrators were the norm after that. J. D. Martin, the first black president of the school, had been born into slavery. Though the school began in a log cabin, as was typical of most schools in the region, Brainerd grew rapidly into a campus of several buildings and 400 students during its heyday in the 1920's. There were tennis and basketball courts as well as a girls' dormitory housed in a pre-Civil War mansion. The school became known for its standards and curriculum, which included Latin and other languages as well as music. 
"We were taxed academically and kept busy with extracurricular activities around the clock," Ms. Ayers said. "We recited 'Thanatopsis' and all of the catechism in the seventh grade, and we learned Milton. When I had children and looked for a school like Brainerd, I couldn't find one. There has never been another one like it." 
Tuition was $5 a month in Ms. Ayers's school days, and farm families who could not pay money, paid with produce to feed the student boarders. Ms. Ayers recalls the music teacher who nurtured her talent for the piano, as well as happy days spent learning Shakespeare and Irish songs that were the heritage of the white teachers. "Black militants today would be horrified," she said, "by what they would call a Eurocentric curriculum." 
Brainerd students, she added, were sheltered from racism by the school's family-like atmosphere. 
"It was like being in a capsule," she said. "There was no opportunity for negative experiences. The whites who came to sing, teach and pray were more than polite. I grew up without racial incidents." 
"We have to memorialize those whites," said Ms. Ayers who founded the Adept New American Museum in Mount Vernon, which is devoted to the achievements of black artists. "They taught you everything they knew and demanded that you learn it." 
Ms. Ayers's sister, Sarah Mildred Ayers Smith, who was valedictorian of the class of 1937 and retired in 1981 as chairwoman of the high school science department in Statesboro, Ga., said she could not recall being disciplined by her teachers, except by being made to memorize an extra chapter of catechism. But the school's expectations extended to social as well as academic life, she said. "Boys and girls had classes together, but there were no junior or senior proms, no dances. Instead there were banquets, with grand marches afterward. We would wait for the grand march so we could hold hands." 
Ms. Ayers, her sister and four other graduates, including a 95-year-old member of the class of 1925, were among 70 people, black and white, who gathered here recently for the dedication of the Brainerd Memorial Project. Guests from as far away as Los Angeles sipped iced tea in the warm sunshine outside Kumler Hall -- which had been stripped of an overgrowth of vines for the occasion -- and reminisced about a place they took for granted as children but have cherished ever since. 
They recalled the maple trees that turned majestic in the fall, the rows of pecan trees that lined a now-vanished walkway and the playing fields where Sara Brown Cordery, class of 1939, excelled in basketball and track. "No one could catch her," Ms. Ayers said, smiling at her classmate. "She could steal your boyfriends, too." 
They also recalled how Brainerd families sold chickens and eggs to help save the school, and the feeling, after it closed, that someone had died. 
After visiting the school, the reunion group gathered for speeches and a musical service in nearby Carmel Presbyterian Church, where generations of the Ayers family had held weddings, baptisms and funerals, and where a stained-glass window bore the family name. "I used to sit in these pews and misbehave terribly," said Ms. Rashad, who also lives in Mount Vernon and who visited Chester as a child. 
Guests held fans carrying the likeness of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as Ms. Ayers introduced the speakers. 
Robert Bainbridge, an architect in South Carolina, said restoring Kumler Hall, would cost $2 million to $3 million but would preserve the story of a people. 
"Many African-American schools have been neglected, and we're losing those stories," he said.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: MANHATTAN; 
Diversity Comes to a Place With a Retail Pedigree

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The advertising agency Foote, Cone & Belding has agreed to lease 270,000 square feet at 100 West 33rd Street, completing the conversion of the century-old building from an unsuccessful vertical mall to one that will have a mix of office, retail and showroom tenants.
 "It will be three buildings," said Mark A. Teitelbaum, a principal in Argent Ventures, which owns the building, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, near Herald Square. The building once housed Gimbels, then Abraham & Straus and then Stern's department store and along the way became known as the Manhattan Mall. 
 The top four floors of the 11-story building will continue to be occupied by showrooms for children's apparel, Mr. Teitelbaum said. The lowest two floors and two levels below ground will house retail space. The floors in between will be converted to offices for Foote, Cone & Belding and for Bank of America, which earlier this year leased 180,000 square feet for operations displaced from the World Trade Center and to consolidate from other sites. 
Having the three categories of tenants is attractive from a landlord's point of view, said Andrew S. Penson, another official of Argent. "We are diversified on cash flow and risk," he said.
Mitchell S. Steir, vice chairman of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage firm that represented Argent, said: "This is the repositioning of a major asset. The goal was to do one or two transactions to lease up the office space for a long term and to do it quickly."
He said the large 90,000-square-foot floors available in the building were attractive to office tenants even in a market in which the demand for offices has been soft because of a slack economy. Large floors, he said, permit the efficient placement of people, with proportionately less space lost to elevators and stairwells than in buildings with smaller floors.
The building, which was completed at the turn of the last century, underwent a gut rehabilitation in 1989 at a cost of more than $400 million, Mr. Teitelbaum said. The building became a vertical shopping mall anchored at first by Abraham & Straus and later by Stern's. The stores, perched on top of a confluence of subway lines and the PATH tubes, did well, but not well enough to support the debt incurred in the rehabilitation, Mr. Teitelbaum said.
Customers complained that the escalators linking the floors were poorly positioned, forcing them to make long detours to move between floors. Nevertheless, lunchtime crowds flocked to a food court that was on the seventh floor, Mr. Teitelbaum said, producing sales of $25 million annually. The food court will be moved to the second level below ground, where stores will be accessible to subway and PATH riders as well as workers from area buildings.
Although the location did not draw enough shoppers, the transportation links were essential for the office tenants, said I. Keith Ellis, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG, a brokerage company that represented Foote, Cone & Belding. He said the ad agency, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies that has its flagship offices at 150 East 42nd Street, wanted a good location and a place that suggested creativity, in a building with floors big enough that units of the agency could be grouped together rather than spread among many floors.
He said the building, with a glass-enclosed interior atrium and views of a refurbished park on Greeley Square, fit those requirements. "Creativity is their product, and they wanted space that would energize their staff," Mr. Ellis said. "The atrium will bring light into two-acre floorplates that otherwise would be pretty dark."
The space has been vacant about a year and will now be completely reconstructed, delaying the agency's move until the second quarter of next year. But with a 20-year lease, the agency wants to take care in designing and building space it will be occupying a long time, Mr. Ellis said.
The main lobby on 33rd Street will be enlarged into space once occupied by Stern's and will have displays promoting the presence of the advertising agency. 
Executives involved in the transaction declined to give the rents involved. Asking rents for older buildings in that part of Manhattan have averaged in the low $40's per square foot annually, according to information published by the CoStar Group, a real estate reporting company.
Real estate executives said the advertising agency's decision to lease the space was important because it was not driven by an event, like the effects of Sept. 11 or the imminent expiration of a lease.
"This is a discretionary transaction, which is something the market has not seen in recent months," Mr. Steir said. "I think it says to the real estate community and the city that business is becoming stronger."

Andersen Trial in Phoenix Opens With Views of Fraud
A civil trial against Arthur Andersen began in Phoenix with a lawyer for the plaintiffs, a Baptist foundation whose books the firm audited, maintaining that Andersen had ignored warnings that the charity was a Ponzi scheme years before it collapsed.
 Andersen's lead lawyer told the jury that the firm was a victim of fraud and that by Dec. 5, 1996, "every member of the board" of the foundation knew of the fraud, as did lawyers and accountants who worked for it. Page C8. 

A House committee has refused to turn over notes and records of interviews with David B. Duncan, the Andersen partner who orchestrated the destruction of Enron documents. C8.

Study Points to Disparity in Lending
A far greater share of black and Hispanic homeowners with above-average incomes still have mortgages with higher interest rates than whites with comparable incomes, according to a study to be released today. A23.

Shares of Edison Schools Halt Slide
Shares of Edison Schools, the nation's largest for-profit operator of public schools, halted a weeklong slide that had eroded more than half the stock's value. Its shares began dropping after April 17, when a state panel overseeing the Philadelphia school system voted to give the company control of 20 failing schools -- 25 fewer than expected. C2.

UAL Begins Search for Top Executive
UAL is starting a search for a chief executive. Jack Creighton, who took the post temporarily last October after James E. Goodwin was forced out, is stepping down. C4.

The board of Hynix Semiconductor voted unanimously to reject a takeover of most of its assets by Micron Technology saying the price was too low. World Business, Section W.

Ullico Finds Outsider to Lead Inquiry

Dow, Nasdaq and S.& P. Post Gains
The Dow Jones industrials closed up 126.35 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,946.22. The Nasdaq gained 31.30 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,688.23, while the Standard & Poor's 500 was up 11.47 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,076.92. C8.

Consumer Confidence Off Slightly
Consumer confidence fell during April, the Conference Board reported. Its gauge of sentiment dropped to 108.8 from 110.7 in March. The drop was less than expected. C8.

I.B.M.'s Chairman Signs Book Deal
Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman and former chief executive of I.B.M., has discreetly negotiated a deal to publish a book about his tenure. Unlike most executive-authors, he has already quietly written much of it by himself. He famously took I.B.M. from a hidebound behemoth on the brink of collapse to a model of corporate revival. C8.

Displaced Workers May Get Aid
Republicans and Democrats in the Senate reached a tentative agreement on providing help to workers who lose their jobs to international competition. A23.

Mixed-Use Project in Dallas Stalls
A proposed 20-acre mixed-use development in downtown Dallas has been stalled in a fight over the amount of city financing it needs. Commercial Real Estate. C6.

HEADLINE: China's Communists Try to Decide What They Stand For 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 28 

 BODY:
Over dinner at a crowded restaurant in central Beijing, a longstanding Communist Party member who works for the government spoke words that would have been unfit for public consumption just a few years ago.
 "What does the Communist Party stand for now?" he asked matter-of-factly. "Nothing. Stability maybe. But really no ideals at all." 
 Responding to a mounting identity crisis that has swept through its ranks in the last few years, China's ruling Communist Party has started searching aggressively for a new set of principles and policies to define its future, reforms intended to ensure its relevance and survival in this increasingly market-oriented, pluralistic society. 
Beginning last year, once closed party institutes have invited a large number of foreign political scientists, including harsh critics of the current government, to lecture and give their advice on China's future. 
Researchers have been sent to Europe and elsewhere to study social democratic parties and to see how former Communist parties weathered transitions to democracy.
Official party publications are sprinkled with calls for political reform, though they are still mostly muted. At some meetings, retired party members have wondered aloud why elections, now common in rural villages, are not being extended to higher levels.
Experts in and outside China say this is the first time they have seen such serious, widespread discussion in the party about the need to make changes in the political system.
In practice there is little these days that is Communist about China, a country where laid-off workers hunt for jobs, yuppies buy stocks and houses and, since last year, private businessmen have been recruited as party members.
Reform that would include direct challenges to the party's rule is not on the table. It is unclear where all the reformist churning will lead, especially since the primary motivation is self-preservation rather than any faith in the inherent good of ideals like democracy or judicial independence.
This fall Hu Jintao, China's vice president, who is now on his first visit to the United States, will take the helm of the Chinese Communist Party, still the world's largest by far.
 In Washington on Tuesday, Mr. Hu met with Congressional leaders and dined with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. 
The party he will inherit is is scrambling to find new relevance and new tools for governing into the future.
"There has been a lot more discussion of reform in the last two years," said one senior professor at the Central Party School, which trains mid- to high-level party members. "Previously there was little thought given to how to consolidate the party's ruling status or to promote its long-term rule. We never thought it was in question."
The need for reform is now "pretty much a universal sentiment," said Chi Fulin, president of the China Institute for Reform and Development in Hainan Province, a research group. He cautioned that proposals were still vague and members "are still reluctant to deal with specifics."
Current reformist impulses have their roots in speeches by President Jiang Zemin last year in which he warned that the party had to "stay in step with the times," and also his campaign for what he called the "Three Represents."
The basic message of that campaign, now trumpeted in slogans throughout the country, was that the Communist Party should no longer just represent workers but should represent "advanced productive forces, advanced Chinese culture and the fundamental interests of the majority." That is, the party can be all things to all people, promoting the interests not just of workers and farmers but of wealthy entrepreneurs as well.
Already within China, those words have helped broaden the limits of political discussion, emboldening liberals to put forward ideas that previously would not have been spoken aloud, since they would almost certainly have led to serious political trouble.
In a recent class for officials at the Central Party School, which is headed by Vice President Hu, one professor openly ridiculed the Central Committee's powerful propaganda department, which controls all Chinese media, as outdated and too conservative. He was criticized by school authorities but kept his job.
Cao Siyuan, a leading Beijing businessman, who used to keep his opinions to himself, has recently weighed in with lectures and essays proposing political reforms. He recommends that the party be renamed the China Socialist Party and suggests that members of party committees be selected in open elections.
"In China we're talking about industrial reforms, agricultural reforms, educational reforms, so it makes sense that the party needs reform too," Mr. Cao said in an interview. "We have to open the debate about how to reform politics and the party, although of course no domestic media dare raise this issue."
Although loyalty to the Communist Party and its ideals has been slipping for years now, members point to a series of recent events that have finally galvanized its leaders to action and opened the door to change.
A spate of increasingly high-level corruption cases has highlighted the shortcomings of a system in which Communist officials are subjected to few checks and balances.
Also, China's long-awaited entry into the World Trade Organization late last year has put intense pressure on the government to speed up economic and legal reforms so it can stay competitive -- reforms whose pace has been slowed by the stagnant political system. 
China's courts and banks are still primarily beholden to the party, for example, making it hard for them to respond to market needs.
"Unless the government effectively reforms itself, things like the reform of state-owned enterprises and attempts to end corruption are bound to fail," said Mr. Chi of the research institute, who favors greater judicial independence and more democratic methods for selecting officials.
These factors, combined with the end of welfare benefits like housing and health care, have left even many loyalists with attenuated allegiance to the party. Though membership continues to grow, many people are joining or retaining their membership mainly for its practical benefits.
"There is almost no one now who believes in the party for its ideals," said a high-level editor and party member. He added that these days most of the party's support derives from the pragmatic view that it is probably the only organization capable of holding this vast, complex country together, largely because no other political groups are allowed.
"If I walked into my former office and started praising the party, people would look at me like some weirdo," he said.
Suisheng Zhao, a Chinese-born political scientist at the University of Denver, said that in recent visits to government institutes in Beijing he had encountered a new breed of party members who were interested in change, often Western-educated and with little interest in Marxist theory.
For many people, "the collapse of ideology is complete," Professor Zhao said. "They have no use for the ideas of the founding fathers. They are clearly hungry for new ideas."
One idea is the promotion of greater accountability. Some cities, like Nanjing, are asking thousands of citizens to complete evaluations of government offices and officials. Those who score poorly may be dismissed.
The party is also experimenting with new programs concerning what it calls "inner party democracy." A certain number of seats on the nationwide Central Committee that were once appointive are now filled in secret balloting by provincial party officials, an effort to stem patronage. In February a reformist former head of the Party School, Zheng Bijian, traveled to Britain to meet with leaders of the Labor Party. This month the school was host to a lecture by Larry Diamond of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, a critic of authoritarian governments who studies how nations develop democracy.
By Western standards the changes may seem minor, but they are large and significant for China.
Some of the reforms under discussion were raised in the late 1980's, only to be set aside after the crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square in June 1989. 
During that brief period, when liberals within the party held sway, political leaders were pushing reforms on a still thoroughly Communist society. Now the Communist Party is playing catch-up with a radically changed populace.
"The Communist Party is trying very hard to recast themselves," said a Western diplomat who has been involved in planning party study trips to Europe. "They are absolutely obsessed with finding a new way -- although there is always the caveat that they stay in power."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A military policeman patrolled in front of Tiananmen Square in September on the eve of China's National Day. The billboard promoted President Jiang Zemin's ideological guidelines, called the "Three Represents." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Yao Turns Heads Of Fans and Scouts

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 30 

 BODY:
Chad Reeser sneaked around his school like a member of the paparazzi, hiding out in vacant stairwells, peering through the small square glass of the gymnasium door. Reeser, a 20-year-old student at Moody Bible Institute, was like the rest of the curiosity seekers who lined the corridors of this downtown private college. On the day of Yao Ming's first audition with the N.B.A., Reeser wanted to catch of glimpse of the 7-foot-5 center from China.
 "I just want to see if he can dunk the ball without jumping," Reeser said. "He is so big. Not just his height; his calves are big. He's huge." 
 Earlier, hotel maids clamored for space in the lobby as he left for his clandestine workout with the Knicks this afternoon, walking beside him with mouths agape.
Yao had to duck in the elevator and contort himself into the passenger seat of a Lincoln Navigator.
He does not plan to speak with reporters during his workouts here, a trip set up to ensure Yao is considered among the first three selections in the June draft. But his size and skill have already spoken for him.
"We felt fortunate that we were able to spend time with him," Scott Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, said after a brief 25-minute workout and an extended conversation with Yao through an interpreter. "I think Yao Ming has special potential. He really does. He is highly skilled and he's a guy that I think will work and improve. I think he'll be great for the league."
The Knicks are one of only two teams to be granted a private workout, along with the Chicago Bulls -- who are expected to conduct a workout with Yao on Thursday. Yao will have a 45-minute workout on Wednesday at Loyola University with 25 other teams. Jeff Van Gundy, the former Knicks coach, was going to be in charge of the workout but the Knicks, who still hold Van Gundy's contractual rights, protested Van Gundy being a part of a showcase for the rest of the N.B.A. P. J. Carlesimo will replace Van Gundy, and Yao will work out with Oregon's Chris Christoffersen.
Yao traveled from Shanghai with Li Yao Min, the general manager of the Shanghai Sharks, and Ye Li, a translator who works for the team's television station. He was met here by Eric Zhang, a distant cousin of Yao's who is his representative.
Li said not too much should be made of Yao granting the Knicks a private workout, given that the team has only a 4.4 percent chance of winning the draft lottery. "Yao Ming doesn't belong to any team," Li said. "He belongs to the world."
One of Yao's interpreters maintained that he has no distinct preference where he wants to play, saying, "Yao thinks the N.B.A. picks me, I don't pick them." But, the interpreter said, he would feel more comfortable in a major metropolitan area with Chinese influences than somewhere completely foreign to his homeland.
None of Yao's entourage seemed to think either economics or politics would hold Yao back from joining the league this season.
He is free to join any team after Sept. 8, when the world basketball championships end in Indianapolis.
His first day in Chicago was filled with commitments. In the morning, Yao paid a visit to the Chinese consulate. In the early afternoon, he met with Bill Walton, the Hall of Fame center who told the 22-year-old Yao what to expect in the N.B.A. after presenting him with tie-dyed apparel promoting Walton's 30-day tour of the league.
"You look very young in your T-shirt," Yao told Walton, who laughed. 
Yao finally made his way to Moody, where his rolling hooks fell softly through the net.
The stride had more grace and elan to it than awkwardness. In a bit of a sneak preview, Yao gave the Knicks and their 12-member contingent a brief glimpse of his skill and talent prior to working out for nearly every N.B.A. team today. 
The scene was a sight to behold. Gym personnel cleared the premises of students. No one was allowed to witness the workout, unless you peered through a door in the back of the gym. 
Outside, a fleet of black town cars lined the back of the gymnasium, idling as if they were about to whisk some diplomat to the airport for a world-altering decision. Yao's arrival may not be that significant, but he has already swung the pendulum of the N.B.A. draft.
The Knicks were coy in their assessment, but clearly believed he had a chance to be a bona fide center in the league very soon. Yao's supporters were even more encouraging.
Waiting for their country's beloved basketball star to emerge from the gymnasium and pose with the Sears Tower in the background, Li spoke of potential.
"Yao will be better than Shaquille O'Neal, especially now in the free throw," he said, smiling. "If they bet steak for free throw, Shaquille O'Neal will invite Yao Ming every time."
The Knicks have scouted Yao three times, with Layden making two trips. They even flew out Coach Don Chaney and Allan Houston to meet with him.
Houston said he was impressed with Yao's skills. At one point, Houston encouraged Yao to take a 3-pointer. Yao shot back in Chinese, laughing. The interpreter told Houston, "He said Patrick Ewing doesn't take threes."
The N.B.A. is concerned whether the Chinese government and the many support systems in Yao's career would hamper his arrival. Already, Yao must give back a significant portion of his salary in accordance with rules governing athletes supported by the state system. 
People surrounding Yao today were hopeful that he would clear the hurdles to play next year in the N.B.A.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
After Only A Month, 4 Managers Are Gone

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Major league managers probably will not want to pick the numbers 6, 15, 22 and 23 for the next Big Game lottery. Those were the numbers that turned out to be unlucky for four members of their clan, Tony Muser of Kansas City becoming the fourth yesterday.
 The Royals ended the managers' Appalling April by firing Muser 23 games into their season. Previously, Phil Garner of Detroit went down after 6 games, Davey Lopes of Milwaukee after 15 and Buddy Bell of Colorado after 22. 
 Never before had four major league managers been fired in April, and that is not counting Joe Kerrigan, who was dismissed by Boston's new owners during spring training.
"There won't be any more in April," Bob Rosen of the Elias Sports Bureau said yesterday, before being reminded that at that moment, the month had 10 1/2 hours remaining in the Pacific time zone.
Elias and the Baseball Hall of Fame Library confirmed that the Royals' move with Muser set a record. Only once before, in 1892, had as many as three managers been fired in April.
The managerial massacre, however, may not be over. May Mayhem could be on the horizon. Buck Martinez of Toronto and Jerry Narron of Texas are in peril, and although it is less likely that the Chicago Cubs would dismiss Don Baylor and Philadelphia would replace Larry Bowa, those teams are none too happy about their first month.
Muser was in his sixth season with the Royals. Their .348 winning percentage (8-15) this season was their worst under him, but even their best, .475, represented a losing season, 77-85 in 2000. The latest deposed manager took his demise philosophically.
"Everybody understands the circumstances, the mood of our fans," Muser said in Detroit, where the Royals won their last game under him Monday night. "They need a change. It's just a part of this business. Managers are hired to be fired. I understand it, and life goes on. The most important thing is the success of the organization."
But the Royals and the other teams that fired their managers in April have played many seasons without success. The Royals, with a $47 million payroll, are the top-paying team among the nine teams with payrolls of less than $50 million, but unlike Oakland and Minnesota, two others in their economic neighborhood, they do not have pitching good enough to compete. The team's earned run average, 5.58 entering last night's game, was 13th in the American League.
The Royals' batting average was also 13th, they were 12th in runs scored and they were last in home runs. Last year, the Royals traded two of their best hitters, Johnny Damon and Jermaine Dye, rather than sign them to multiyear contracts before they could become free agents.
Unlike Oakland and Minnesota, the Royals are down in attendance this season, off 50,000 from April 2001. The Royals evidently hope a change in managers will serve as a spark to the team, which could then win some games and attract more fans to Kauffman Stadium.
John Mizerock, in his first year as the Royals' bullpen coach after managing in their minor league system for nine years, was named interim manager. General Manager Allard Baird said Mizerock, a former major league catcher, will be a candidate for the job on a more permanent basis. Obviously, managing jobs are anything but permanent.
"He has a history with a lot of the guys on the major league level and throughout our organization," Baird said, explaining his decision. "As an organization, we felt that we were not succeeding. It was the right time."
Teams have come a long way from the days when George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, was ridiculed for firing Bob Lemon after 14 games (1982) and Yogi Berra after 16 games (1985). The increased cost of payrolls has made it mandatory for managers -- and general managers -- to win.
That kind of pressure was not present in 1892, but three National League managers were nevertheless fired in April. Washington dismissed Billy Barnie after two games, St. Louis dropped the playing manager Jack Glasscock after four games and Baltimore relieved the playing manager George Van Haltren of his managing duties after 11 games.

HEADLINE: The Fall of a Telecom Gunslinger 

 BODY:
The ultimate deal maker has been dealt away. Under pressure from his board of directors, Bernard Ebbers, perhaps the most celebrated telecom entrepreneur of the last quarter century, has resigned as chief executive of WorldCom, the beleaguered communications empire he stitched together with more than 75 acquisitions. The abrupt departure of Mr. Ebbers, first reported in yesterday's Wall Street Journal, provides a fitting exclamation mark to the meltdown of the nation's telecom sector, which has cost shareholders a staggering $2 trillion. 
 Though born in Canada, Mr. Ebbers is a quintessentially American maverick entrepreneur who thrived by upsetting the establishment. While managing motels in Mississippi in 1983, Mr. Ebbers saw an opportunity in Ma Bell's impending breakup and decided to start a company called LDDS, or Long Distance Discount Service. 
 Through a series of frantic deals that leveraged its ever-rising stock price, that company evolved into WorldCom, the leading carrier of Internet traffic and the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company. WorldCom embodies the excesses of the 1990's stock market bubble and the unfulfilled aspirations of telecommunications deregulation. 
Unlike other populist capitalists who have acquired near folk-hero status in corporate America -- think of Herb Kelleher of Southwest Airlines and Sam Walton -- Mr. Ebbers was more interested in doing deals than in ensuring that his company was well managed. WorldCom now faces a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its accounting practices. At issue is whether the company fudged the books on its dizzying array of mergers or engaged in revenue-swap deals with others to exaggerate its profits. The S.E.C. is also seeking information about $366 million in low-interest loans and loan guarantees the company extended to Mr. Ebbers, an egregious case of executive compensation abuse that shareholders rightly deplore.
WorldCom's larger problem is the weakness of its core businesses. Much of the telecom slump is due to the fact that too many people emulating WorldCom rushed out to build excess capacity. In the phone arena, MCI, a unit of WorldCom, has been punished along with AT&T and other long-distance players by plummeting rates and an inability to compete on a level playing field with the regional Baby Bells. Having sacked its founder, WorldCom's own day of reckoning may be drawing near.

HEADLINE: Andersen Trial in Phoenix Opens With Views on Fraud 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, April 30 

 BODY:
The trial of Arthur Andersen's second-largest financial problem -- its audits of a Baptist foundation that collapsed and led to criminal prosecutions -- began today with a plaintiffs' lawyer maintaining that Andersen had ignored warnings that the charity was a Ponzi scheme years before the foundation fell apart.
 "This is a case about the terrible things that can happen when auditors do not do what we pay them to do," said John P. Coffey, a partner with Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossmann who is the lead attorney for the Arizona Baptist Foundation bankruptcy liquidation trust. Andersen, he said, went "from being a negligent auditor to being complicit in the fraud." 
 The Baptist foundation had borrowed money from investors and used it to invest in real estate, promising that its profits would go to pay for Baptist charitable projects. When the Arizona real estate market declined, Mr. Coffey said, the foundation's management found ways to avoid that reality, largely by setting up shell corporations to buy real estate from the foundation at inflated prices, with the foundation lending the money for the purchases. 
When the foundation collapsed in 1999, it owed $570 million, mostly to elderly investors who had been attracted by high interest rates. William Crotts, the foundation's former chief executive, has pleaded not guilty to criminal fraud charges and has told lawyers that he will invoke his Fifth Amendment right to avoid testifying in the civil case.
Andersen's lead lawyer, Don Martin, told the jury today that Andersen was a victim of fraud. "It was a fraud," he said. "It misled investors. It defrauded its own auditor, Arthur Andersen." He said that by Dec. 5, 1996, "every member of the board" of the foundation knew of the fraud, as did lawyers and accountants who worked for the foundation. "They knew about the fraud, and they kept quiet," he said.
In an opening statement that never mentioned the Enron Corporation, Mr. Coffey nevertheless managed to invoke echoes of the charges of obstruction of justice that Andersen will face in a federal trial that begins next week in Houston.
He told of memorandums reflecting warnings the firm had received as early as 1997 about the Baptist foundation's financial statements. Those memos did not show up in Andersen files, but still came to light.
One memo, found in Baptist foundation files, reports that Andersen planned in 1998 to check the finances of one of the shell corporations. That memo did not show up in Andersen files, he said, and the inspection was never done, even after a series of articles in the Phoenix newspaper New Times, which was based on interviews with disgruntled former employees of the foundation.
Mr. Coffey said that even though the newspaper identified its sources by name, Andersen auditors did not bother to call any of them before reassuring state officials that there was no cause for concern about the foundation's finances.
Mr. Martin, the Andersen lawyer, said all the warnings referred to by Mr. Coffey came after the board already knew of the fraud. He said Andersen acted properly in considering them and should not be blamed for not uncovering the fraud.
Mr. Martin pointed out to the jury that the plaintiff in the case was the bankruptcy trustee now overseeing the Baptist foundation, not investors who were hurt. He suggested that it was unfair that Andersen is being sued by the successor to the party that committed the fraud. An investor class-action lawsuit has not yet come to trial, but if money is recovered in this suit it will probably go to the creditors of the foundation, including the defrauded investors.
The small Maricopa County Superior Court courtroom was packed, with a number of elderly people who were victims among the spectators who stood in the aisles. Judge Edward Berke warned the spectators not to say things like "amen" or "yes" in response to statements by lawyers or witnesses. "I empathize with you," he said to the spectators, noting that many had lost money, "but we are going to have a fair trial here."
One spectator, Betty Shoup, 77, a retired secretary who said she and her husband had lost $250,000, said she had thought her money was safe. "We knew they were not federally insured, but they always said, 'We are Godly insured,' " she said in a brief interview.
She said the Baptist Foundation had promised interest rates of up to 15 percent. "They had easy-access accounts, just like checking, but with pretty good interest," she said.
Andersen agreed to settle the case nearly two months ago with a payment of $217 million. But that deal fell apart after Andersen said its insurance company, which is owned by Andersen and its foreign affiliates, could not pay the money because Andersen had not paid up on its premiums. Since then Andersen's ability to pay has been further undermined by client defections.
The trial that began today is expected to last more than a month. For the plaintiffs, who lost hundreds of millions of dollars they invested with the Baptist foundation, there is substantial doubt that they will be able to collect much money even if they do obtain a large verdict. 
"We certainly hope so," Mr. Coffey, the plaintiffs' lawyer, said after being asked if Andersen would be able to pay. "I believe Andersen will do everything they can to survive." If necessary, he said, "we will fight in bankruptcy court."
Asked if Andersen would be in any position to pay when the trial ended, Mr. Martin, the lead attorney for Andersen, responded, "That's a good question." He said he read the newspapers every day looking for answers.
Andersen's official position is that it is trying to reorganize as a smaller company that will be virtually an audit-only firm, as recommended by a panel headed by Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman. But none of the conditions Mr. Volcker viewed as necessary for that to happen have occurred, and few in the accounting industry think Andersen can survive.

HEADLINE: WORLDCOM LEADER DEPARTS COMPANY IN TURBULENT TIME 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Bernard J. Ebbers, who spent 19 years building WorldCom into one of the biggest long-distance companies and Internet carriers in the world, has resigned as chief executive, president and director, the company said yesterday.
 If any executive represented the entrepreneurial epoch that was supposed to make telecommunications cheaper and the choices abundant in an era of deregulation, it was Mr. Ebbers. It was he who exploited the deregulation of the telecommunications industry more than anyone else during the last two decades. With ruthless cost-cutting and fervent deal-making, he showed for years that it was possible to undercut AT&T in the long-distance market and still make a lot of money. 
 But Mr. Ebbers was brought down by wounds that, to some measure, were self-inflicted. He personally owes the company more than $366 million for loans and loan guarantees to cover his potential losses on his WorldCom stock as the share price plummeted. And the company, under his watch, became the subject of a wide-ranging and continuing investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is scrutinizing WorldCom's accounting practices and financial relations with Mr. Ebbers. 
Yet Mr. Ebbers was also undone by industry and economic forces beyond any one executive's or company's control. Page C1. 
While consumers enjoyed the long-distance price wars, the service eventually became a commodity from which few carriers could squeeze a profit, especially as e-mail and cellphones siphoned off traffic. And the glut of network capacity that was built by start-up companies fueled by easy financing during the stock market boom only further depressed network pricing. 
Finally, as the bursting of the stock market bubble in 2000 made it harder for telecommunications companies to raise money and make deals like WorldCom's acquisition of MCI for $30 billion in 1998, the company's growth-by-acquisition engine ran out of gas. 
Mr. Ebbers's departure, which was decided over the weekend, was reported on Tuesday by The Wall Street Journal.
"This is the collapse of the single-most-successful telecom growth company ever," said Scott Cleland, chief executive of the Precursor Group, a telecommunications and media consulting firm in Washington. "It was a momentum story that ran out of momentum. Bernie was a genius at acquiring customers and cutting costs. His genius was not in operating the companies he bought."
WorldCom says that it has enough cash to continue operating indefinitely, despite being staggered by $30 billion in debt and limping along with a share price of about $2.50 -- down 82 percent so far this year. Its bonds are trading at prices normally reserved for companies on the brink of bankruptcy. 
With dozens of other telecommunications upstarts now bankrupt, WorldCom's mounting problems make it increasingly likely that the dominant players in the telecommunications industry may be the remaining offspring of that old antediluvian Bell System: the local telephone giants like BellSouth, SBC Communications and Verizon.
Worldcom's tribulations may have little direct or lasting impact on consumers and business customers because there are many other providers of long-distance and Internet services. But the strong possibility that the Bell companies may step into the breach -- even now, the Bells are slowly being allowed into the long-distance business -- may reveal the limits of the two-decade-old vision that deregulation would give communications customers a broad range of choices among providers. 
And yet, analysts note that the two decades of competitive ferment that Mr. Ebbers helped symbolize have radically changed the communications landscape. With affordable long-distance calls, Internet e-mail, wireless communications, and cable television systems that can also carry telephone calls, consumer communications options now vastly exceed the possibilities of the old Bell System days -- when choice mainly meant picking the color of a phone. 
"I think that the Bells are dominant, but in a world that is far more volatile and far more competitive than it was before," said Blair Levin, a former chief of staff at the Federal Communications Commission who is now an analyst for the investment firm Legg Mason. 
Mr. Levin cited an historical analogy: "In the mid-1800's, the country went berserk building railroads and a lot of investors lost a lot of money. But those railroads created the economic engine that fueled the country's growth through the next century. WorldCom and MCI largely inspired the same thing."
Mr. Ebbers, who was not available for comment yesterday, did not set out to make WorldCom an inspiration. At its inception it was, instead, little more than a gamble.
In 1983, just months before the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company broke up its Bell System to settle a federal antitrust suit, four men gathered in a Hattiesburg, Miss., coffee shop. They knew that the breakup of Ma Bell would open the door for widespread competition in the long-distance telephone market and they met to sketch out plans for a cut-rate telephone company that they called LDDS. They could hardly have expected that their company, renamed WorldCom, would show more than $35 billion in revenue by 2001.
One of those at the coffee shop was Mr. Ebbers, a former junior high school basketball coach from Edmonton, Alberta, who was then running a string of Mississippi motels.
LDDS stood for Long-Distance Discount Service, so naturally, the company's business plan was to undercut AT&T. In the early 1980's, AT&T and even some long-distance upstarts were starting to sell wholesale time on their networks to other companies, time that the smaller companies could resell on the retail market at a profit.
Because of all of the required regulatory approvals and the search for customers, LDDS did not actually get into business until January 1985. Just a few months later, Mr. Ebbers became the company's president.
"The only experience Bernie had before operating a long-distance company was he used the phone," Carl J. Aycock, an original LDDS investor and WorldCom board member, recalled in 1997.
But Mr. Ebbers produced results. From the beginning, the company was distinguished by its aggressive salesmanship, its ruthless cost-cutting and its passion for corporate acquisitions.
Mr. Ebbers's focus on costs earned him garlands from Wall Street, but also prompted whispered concerns that the company might have been too aggressive in its accounting. That may be one issue that the S.E.C. is looking into as it conducts its investigation. Some analysts say the company may have improperly masked operating losses as one-time charges, enhancing its financial operating results.
But despite its revenue growth and cost controls, WorldCom has been built mostly through dozens of acquisitions. In the 1980's, Mr. Ebbers snapped up rafts of other small long-distance companies, companies that appeared much like LDDS itself. After the company became publicly traded in 1989, the deal-making rose to a new level. 
In one of its early breakthrough deals, in 1992, LDDS mounted a $720 million acquisition of the Advanced Telecommunications Corporation. As would be Mr. Ebbers's habit, his company used its own stock as a currency in the transaction, which made LDDS the nation's fourth-biggest telecommunications company, after AT&T, MCI and Sprint.
Perhaps as important, however, that deal brought Mr. Ebbers into contact with Scott D. Sullivan, a young finance executive at Advanced Telecommunications. Mr. Sullivan, now 40, became WorldCom's chief financial officer in 1994 and was hailed by Wall Street analysts and happy WorldCom investors for much of the 1990's as one of the industry's financial wunderkinds.
In yesterday's announcement, WorldCom said that Mr. Sullivan would continue as chief financial officer and would also be promoted to executive vice president. He will report to John Sidgmore, the former vice chairman, who became president and chief executive on Sunday.
As a team, Mr. Sullivan and Mr. Ebbers blazed through the 1990's with a series of bigger and bigger acquisitions. When WorldCom acquired MFS Communications, an up- and-coming local communications provider, the deal brought along Mr. Sidgmore, who had recently persuaded MFS to buy his Internet company, UUNet. 
WorldCom's acquisition binge culminated in the $30 billion acquisition of MCI in 1998. MCI's longtime leader, William McGowan -- the man who had helped force the breakup of AT&T -- had died, and the company was adrift, ripe for Mr. Ebbers's acquisitive taste. At the time of the deal, MCI was more than three times WorldCom's size. 
But Mr. Ebbers's deal-making would find its limit in 2000, when antitrust authorities in Europe and the United States shot down WorldCom's proposed acquisition of Sprint for $129 billion. After that, the acquisitions were less bold, like last year's deal to acquire Intermedia Communications and its Digex Web services subsidiary for $4.1 billion.
During the height of his wheeling and dealing, though, Mr. Ebbers made no secret of the fact that his intentions were purely financial, and that he was less concerned about the fundamentals of his business. 
"Our goal is not to capture market share or be global," he was famously quoted as saying by Business Week in 1997. "Our goal is to be the No. 1 stock on Wall Street."
For many years, that focus made Mr. Ebbers a cult figure on Wall Street. And for good reason. A $100 investment in WorldCom stock at the beginning of 1990 would have been worth about $8,700 when the company's stock hit its peak of $64.50 in 1999. By yesterday, that investment would have been worth about $335.
For a time, even as Mr. Ebbers focused more on his company's stock rather than on his company's operations, investors were happy to go along for the ride.
"I attended many, many of his prayer meetings with the New York Society of Securities Analysts and they just said, 'Anything you want, Bernie, you got it,' " said Howard Anderson, founder of the Yankee Group, a consulting firm in Boston. "They did not examine his finances and his books with anything resembling due diligence."
Mr. Ebbers, to be sure, was not cut from the same cloth as Gary Winnick, the chairman of the telecommunications upstart Global Crossing, who sold over $700 million of his company's stock before the shares collapsed and the company filed for bankruptcy protection.
In fact, Mr. Ebbers appears to be in dire personal financial straits precisely because instead of selling WorldCom shares, he kept buying, sometimes pledging the value of shares he already owned to buy still more. As WorldCom's shares fell over the last 18 months and as the margin calls came in, WorldCom extended those big loans to Mr. Ebbers. 
"Bernie was not Bill McGowan," Mr. Anderson said, referring to the late MCI leader. 
"McGowan understood the delicate balance between customers, network capacity, publicity and raising money," Mr. Anderson said. "Bernie viewed this as a series of financial-engineering maneuvers and never truly understood the business that he was in. In the end, that probably skewered him."

HEADLINE: Wide Racial Disparities Found in Costs of Mortgages 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
A far greater share of black and Hispanic homeowners with above-average incomes still have mortgages with higher interest rates than whites with comparable incomes, according to a study to be released today. The research suggests that conventional banks, despite recent progress, have failed to reach many minority borrowers who would qualify for good mortgages based on their salary and credit history, housing experts said.
 In its most surprising finding, the study said that the racial disparities increased as homeowners' salaries rose. Among households that made at least 120 percent of the typical income in their metropolitan area, 32 percent of blacks held high-interest, or subprime, loans while only 11 percent of whites did. Among households that made 80 percent or less of the typical local salary, 56 percent of blacks had subprime loans and 25 percent of whites did. 
 "The market isn't working as it should," said Allen J. Fishbein, general counsel at the Center for Community Change, a housing advocacy group in Washington that conducted the study. "It's pretty striking."
The study looked at federal records of refinancing loans made in 2000. Such loans are most popular among subprime lenders, many of which are more willing to lend money to people who already own a house that can be used as collateral.
The center is releasing the study in an effort to promote a bill that Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, plans to introduce today in an effort to crack down on so-called predatory lending. The measure would expand the government's definition of high-cost loans and curb some features of these loans, like penalties against borrowers who pay off their mortgages early.
A number of state legislatures, including New Jersey's, are considering other bills aimed at predatory lending. California and North Carolina recently passed such bills.
But many lenders -- including Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which package billions of dollars worth of home mortgages -- oppose the state measures, arguing that they would prevent people who do not have low incomes or blemished credit histories from obtaining loans, or say the legislation should be modified.
Traditional banks have recently expanded their efforts to lend money in minority neighborhoods, partly in response to federal laws that give them incentives to do so and partly in an attempt to find new customers. But many of these neighborhoods are still dominated by mortgage brokers offering subprime loans.
The growth of subprime lending in recent years has helped many people who could not otherwise borrow money to buy homes, but it has also allowed predatory loans to become more common.
St. Louis had the biggest disparity between the percentage of upper-income blacks and upper-income whites who held subprime loans, according to the study. About one of every 20 affluent whites who took out a second mortgage in 2000 received a subprime loan. For blacks, the comparable figures were one in three.
Subprime loans typically have an annual interest rate one to four percentage points higher than a conventional loan. Over the life of a mortgage, the difference often translates into tens of thousands of dollars.
St. Louis was followed by Chicago, San Francisco, New Orleans and Indianapolis. New York ranked 24th out of 331 metropolitan areas.
The disparity between Hispanics and non-Hispanic whites was greatest in Western cities with large Spanish-speaking populations. These include Tucson, Ariz., and Salinas, San Francisco and San Jose in California. New York ranked 13th.
The study's authors acknowledged that their findings did not prove that minority borrowers unfairly pay high mortgage rates, because applicants' credit histories were not considered. But the authors said the gaps between subprime lending to whites and minority borrowers were probably too big to reflect only credit differences. Some other housing experts, told of the findings, agreed. "On the surface, it sounds right," said Jeffrey Zeltzer, executive director of the National Home Equity Mortgage Association, which represents subprime lenders. For years, many banks denied credit to minority borrowers, Mr. Zeltzer said, and some people continue to borrow from subprime lenders, out of habit or fear that banks will reject them.
Housing experts said they could not fully explain why the gap between whites and minorities grew as income rose. One possibility is that banks discriminate against minorities, rejecting them for loans that whites with similar income and credit history receive. Bankers strongly deny that, and Mr. Fishbein, one of the study's authors, said researchers found no evidence to the contrary.
Mr. Fishbein said another possible explanation is that subprime lending is concentrated in minority neighborhoods. Minority applicants with high incomes who live in these neighborhoods might borrow from subprime lenders after seeing their ads and storefronts much more often than those of traditional banks.
Douglas Duncan, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said the significant rise in minority income in the last five years could also have played a role. Minorities' income may have effectively leaped ahead of their credit quality, which suffered during years when they made less money, giving banks a reason to reject their applications.
