HEADLINE: Slave Policies 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
IN 1856, just five years before the outbreak of the Civil War, the Charter Oak Life Insurance Company printed a pamphlet offering slave owners in six Southern states the option of insuring the lives of their slaves.
 For just $2, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee residents, for example, could purchase a 12-month policy from the Hartford-based insurer on a 10-year-old domestic servant that would yield $100 if the slave died. Policies for older slaves, like a 45-year-old, were more expensive, costing the slave owner $5.50 a year. 
 Though the company no longer exists, these policies are drawing increasing attention nearly 150 years later because of a lawsuit that was filed in United States District Court in Brooklyn, in late March against Aetna Inc. and two other companies, claiming that they profited from the slave trade.
In Connecticut, where insurance has long been a principal industry, the documents exhibit a painful reminder of the past, especially in a Northern state that is proud of its abolitionist ancestors like John Brown. 
"It's not pleasant to talk about it today, to put it mildly, but slaves were insured just like any other thing that the farmers owned, that the slave owners owned," said Tom Baker, director of the Insurance Law Center at the University of Connecticut School of Law. "If you were selling insurance in slave states to people who had plantations, that was one of the things that you sold.
"It was very common," he added. "Basically, insurance and slavery go all the way back as far as American history."
Aetna, which in 2000 apologized for its involvement in slavery, is the only insurance company to be named in the slave reparations lawsuit, though one of the plaintiff's lawyers, Roger S. Wareham, said he expected that other insurance companies would be sued. 
A brief examination of documents demonstrates that Aetna was hardly the only company that engaged in the practice. 
"It wasn't just the Aetna company," said Charles L. Blockson, curator of the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection at Temple University. "A lot of the old insurance companies, especially the ones that handled shipping in the Newport, R.I., area and New London."
The problem for the plaintiffs, experts said, is that many firms are defunct, have changed names, destroyed old records, or have been absorbed by other companies. In addition, it is sometimes difficult to document ties to the slave trade.
In the case of slave ships, for example, 19th-century marine insurance policies often didn't identify the cargo on board. Instead, the policy simply stated that it insured "goods" on board.
"What strikes me from what I know already is that the records do not say clearly that slaves were insured," said Ugo Nwokeji, assistant professor of history at UConn. "We cannot say that we know it was widespread, although it is well possible that it would have been widespread."
The insurance industry's connection to slavery is not a new revelation. It has been written about in publications like Mr. Blockson's 1977 book, "Black Genealogy." Even on eBay, the Internet auction site, copies of slave life insurance polices are for sale. And the tale of the slave ship Zong, in which 133 sick slaves were thrown overboard in 1781 so the ship's owners could collect insurance, has been studied for years.
The connection has gained greater attention in recent years because of the research of Deadria Farmer-Paellmann, the lead plaintiff in the federal lawsuit that was filed on March 26 against Aetna, the FleetBoston Financial Corporation and the CSX Corporation. Ms. Farmer-Paellmann first stumbled across slave insurance policies in 1997 while researching a slave reparations paper for a law school class. After reviewing different courses of action, she decided to focus on corporations and private estates that had been involved in slavery. 
"And that's how I came into Aetna," she said.
Ms. Farmer-Paellmann, who said she is a descendant of slaves, continued to pursue the issue long after her class ended. In 2000, she called Aetna and requested that they send her copies of their policies. She said she received two.
"I was really moved when I saw the policies," she said. "It's one thing to read about it and it's another thing to actually see a copy of the policy, and it really caused me to pause. I have to say it was a very emotional experience." 
So, she decided, it would be appropriate if Aetna apologized and paid retributions. 
In March 2000, Aetna expressed "deep regret" that for a few years after its founding in 1853, Aetna Life Insurance insured the lives of slaves. Calling it a "sad" and "disappointing chapter" in the company's history, Aetna has said it only issued a "small number" of such policies. To date, the company has records of five policies on 16 lives and is aware of two policies that appeared in books, according to a company spokesman, who, because of the pending litigation, referred additional questions to a statement on the company's Web site. 
In one policy, a woman named Mary Raby purchased a 12-month policy for $17.25 from Aetna's New Orleans office in October 1853. If the insured slave or slaves died, Ms. Raby would receive $600, according to a copy of the policy that appears in Dee Parmer Woodtor's book "Finding a Place Called Home: A Guide to African-American Genealogy and Historical Identity" (Random House, 1999).
Shortly after Aetna issued its apology, the California State Legislature passed a bill requiring all insurance companies that do business in the state to submit records of any slaveholder insurance policies.
To date, eight companies have submitted information, said Nancy Cramer, deputy press secretary for the California Department of Insurance. Five sent policies and the other three sent information on ships they may have insured, she said. The documents were released to the public last Wednesday.
The California law has prompted companies like Ace Ltd., a Bermuda-based insurance company, to search through archives looking for connections to the slave trade. The company hired a law firm to review its archives, including the records of Aetna Fire and Insurance Company and the Insurance Company of North America. Those companies later became part of Cigna's property and casualty holdings that Ace acquired in 1999. Ace did not find any evidence of slave life insurance policies written by Aetna Fire or the Insurance Company of North America, according to Lisa Fleishman-Hicks, a spokeswoman for Ace.
And though the Insurance Company of North America is one of the oldest insurance companies in the country, Ace compared its marine insurance records against those of known slave vessels and did not find that it had written or carried any policies on known slave vessels, Ms. Fleishman-Hicks said.
For companies that engaged in the practice, it was not necessarily a profitable business. In fact, the Hartford Life Insurance Company went out of business, in part, because of its practice of insuring slaves, according to P. Henry Woodward's 1897 book, "Insurance in Connecticut." The business, which is not related to the current company of the same name, "tried the experiment" with insuring slaves "by shiploads," according to the book.
"Although premiums were very high, they were still far from remunerative," he wrote. "As a rule, the worst masters took out policies. Negroes were described as Caesar or Cato, Jim or Tom, and identification was so difficult that if any of a gang died, names in the proofs of loss were easily fitted to them."
In addition, he wrote, the shippers knew the average percentage of loss "and hence had every advantage in arranging terms."
And even though Charter Oak Life Insurance offered policies on slaves, it was not necessarily a business it wanted to encourage, according to the 1856 pamphlet. 
"The company is by no means solicitous of securing a large Negro insurance business unless the owners are careful and judicial men," Matthew Magill, a Kentucky-based general agent for Charter Oak Life Insurance, wrote in the 1856 pamphlet. 
With documents showing that other companies engaged in the practice, is it right that Aetna, which said it has spent $36.5 million in the past 20 years on health initiatives and scholarships, among other things, for African-Americans , bear the burden of the insurance industry's involvement in the slave trade? 
Mr. Baker of UConn, for one, doesn't think so.
"I just have a sense that it's unfair that a few companies have been singled out when the slave economy was something that the whole society bears some responsibility for," Mr. Baker said.
"My concern," he added, "is more that to the extent that there is some moral responsibility, it should not be targeted to just a few people."
Ms. Farmer-Paellmann said companies like Aetna are being held accountable for their past practices. Other businesses, she said, will be singled out in the future.
"This is, like I said, the first step," Ms. Farmer-Paellmann said. "They have played a role and they should be held responsible, and later on down the road there will be more companies."

HEADLINE: A Man Once Called 'Hero' Just Wants a Job 

BYLINE:  By JANE GORDON 

 BODY:
A SMALL statue of Michael the Archangel is set atop Ed Smith's television, testament to what the people of Farmington think of him. The angel Michael was known as God's warrior, a mighty angel often portrayed in armor who cast Satan from the heavens. A family from Farmington made the statue as a gift to Mr. Smith. "For you," it reads, "who is the guardian and protector of all people."
 Ed Smith is no angel, he'll be the first to admit that. He has no armor either, which he could use about now. In March, he gave up trying to save his career as a 13-year employee of the Southbury Training School, an institution for mentally retarded people. Then a few weeks later the IGA in Wolcott laid him off, saying the store just wasn't doing enough business. His unemployment benefits ran out long ago. 
 Now he spends much of his time filling out job applications or pondering his fate in his home overlooking Lake Winnemaug in Watertown. Wherever he goes in the Waterbury area, whether it is to the Home Depot or the local temporary agency, people stop him and ask, "Aren't you the guy? . . ." 
Mr. Smith said he doesn't want to be that guy anymore, but admits he wouldn't act differently today. Three years ago he alerted a neighborhood in Farmington that a Southbury patient, who had been labeled by the state as a "same-sex opportunistic pedophile," was being moved to a group home there. Neighbors stopped the move and hailed Mr. Smith as a hero, but he was arrested for illegally removing patient records. His life has been in turmoil since, and the letters and checks that crammed the post office box of Citizens for Ed Smith have dwindled.
"Here today," he said without bitterness, "history tomorrow."
Mr. Smith's tale started in May 1999, when he heard at work that the man the state called a pedophile, who came to be known only as E. G., was to be moved to the group home from Southbury. Despite protests from staff members, the administration at Southbury, Mr. Smith said, continued to plan the move, which had been ordered by the State Department of Mental Retardation.
Several months later, Mr. Smith drove to Farmington with his fiancee, Michelle Rasmussen, who also worked at Southbury. They ostensibly were going out to dinner, although Mr. Smith wanted to see for himself if the group home was far from other houses, and particularly from children, as he had come to believe.
But when he stopped at the house, he saw it was part of a neighborhood. An older woman was in a yard next door, separated only by a chain-link fence, watching the children in her care play.
Whenever he tells this story, his face reddens so fully one fears he will burst a blood vessel. His eyes fill with tears. But the words keep coming, flowing from his mouth as effortlessly as water from a spout. "I'm no Paul Revere," he said, "no whistle-blower. I just saw this woman, the kids. And I got a knot in my stomach."
Mr. Smith walked over to the woman and began to chat. Had she heard about the new residents? Oh, yes, the woman, Rosemary Carpenter, the children's aunt, said. She had heard an elderly couple were moving in. Why, she and the children were going to bake muffins and take them over once the couple moved in. Mr. Smith cautioned her against any such generosity. He told her, he said, the truth, and she became upset.
He left, and saw a police officer in the neighborhood. Mr. Smith advised the officer that Mrs. Carpenter may need some reassurance about the neighborhood's safety now that she knew who was moving in. With that second conversation, the word was out, and Farmington's ire was up.
After that day, just about every move Mr. Smith had made became news. Farmington residents praised him. But to the administration at Southbury, he was a man who leaked confidential information. To state prosecutors, he was a lawbreaker. The police arrested him. His trial attracted the attention of news media outlets throughout the country. " 'Dateline' came out to the house," he said. "They got lost."
As word spread, the facts changed to suit the telling, Mr. Smith said. He said he never stole any records and never distributed anything to residents' mailboxes, as had initially been reported. He talked to Mrs. Carpenter and gave her his copy of minutes to a meeting documenting E. G.'s attempts to lure a 7-year-old boy to his bedroom window while he was in Southbury. Then he talked to the police officer and left. He said that is all he did.
He was acquitted by a jury in January. After the trial, several Democratic state legislators asked for his help. They wanted to draft a bill creating an oversight board authorized to investigate concerns regarding sex offenders in state care. But that was a volunteer effort -- no job there. His numerous supporters held three fund-raisers to help pay the fees for his lawyer, Stephen McEleney of Hartford. Still, "I haven't even scratched the surface to get this gentleman paid," Mr. Smith said. He still owes Mr. McEleney $48,000.
He collected unemployment for the first 26 weeks, then installed wallboard and painted when he could find the work. He landed a job at a furniture store, but business slowed after Sept. 11 and he was let go. Mr. Smith has applied to various agencies that care for the elderly and for special-needs children, but no one has offered him a job.
Mr. Smith wanted his old, steady job back, the one he felt certain he did well, and the one for which he was justly compensated. Who else would hire him for $25 an hour, a guy without a college degree and little experience when he first started out? But for his fiancee to regain her job at Southbury, he had to agree to resign his own, which he did in March. He also had to sign off on an apology to E. G., who has remained at Southbury.
Southbury referred all questions to the State Department of Mental Retardation. Martin Zito, chief of staff at the department, refused to answer questions about the case over the telephone. In response to questions submitted to him in an e-mail message, he wrote that Mr. Smith was fired for "a violation of D.M.R. work rules."
Mr. Zito did not answer submitted questions about Mr. Smith's work record while at Southbury and whether the department would consider hiring him back. In response to those questions, Mr. Zito instead wrote:
"The Connecticut Department of Mental Retardation has reached a full and final resolution of the grievance regarding the dismissal of the grievant, Edward Smith with New England Healthcare District 1199, which was negotiated through the Connecticut Office of Labor Relations. As is evident by the signed agreement, all parties have agreed to the details set forth and D.M.R. officials believe this negotiated resolution is an appropriate end to an unfortunate incident."
Mr. Smith still shares a house with Ms. Rasmussen, who grew up in it. His two sons, from his first marriage, visit every other weekend. 
His supporters are distressed at the outcome.
"It's terrible," Mrs. Carpenter said. "He's nothing but a hero to me. That's how I look at it and that's how this town looks at it." She and several other Farmington residents call Mr. Smith regularly.
Sometimes he looks at the statue of Michael the archangel and sighs.
"That's not me, I'm not a hero," he said. "But what was I going to do that day, turn the car around and say, 'It's the Department of Mental Retardation's problem'? I'm not that kind of person, so I got out of the car. And I don't regret what I did." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Farmington thanks Ed Smith for action he took three years ago, but he has since lost his jobs. (Don Heiny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Long Island; 
U.S. Open Leads to Makeover of an Aging Clubhouse

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
WHEN the United States Golf Association announced that Bethpage State Park would be the site of the 102nd annual U.S. Open in June 2002, one immediate concern was the condition of the 80-year-old clubhouse, a rambling structure that serves all five courses at the public facility.
 Now, five years after the choice of the park's Black Course -- which straddles the Nassau-Suffolk border -- as the site of the four-day tournament that begins on June 13, the clubhouse has had a $10 million makeover, including construction of a 7,000-square-foot grand ballroom. 
 Seventy-eight corporate tents, which will include food and television sets, will be erected at three sites for the tournament.
Local businesses will also benefit. Some 225 hotels, from Nassau to Riverhead in Suffolk, have been fully booked for the entire week of the Open. 
In addition to making history -- it will be the first time the tournament is held at a public facility, and the 7,214-yard Black Course is the longest in Open history -- the event is expected to give a boost to Long Island's tourism and hotel industry. 
The tournament's overall impact on the island's economy is expected to be $70 million, according to Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau and Sports Commission. "After 9/11, tourism went down by about 40 percent," he said. "It had been a $5 billion a year industry on Long Island. With the U.S. Open here, people will see us all over the world and make decisions to come here."
The tournament involves 156 golfers and their entourages, and more than 42,000 ticket holders a day are expected, according to Marty Parks, senior director of communications for the Golf Association, which invested more than $3 million to modernize and repair the course. "The Black Course was chosen on its merit as a world-class golf course," he said. "Then the outside-the-ropes issues were considered," including hotels and transportation.
"Because it is a public golf course, we negotiated with the state that it be part of the contract that the green fees at Bethpage Black be guaranteed not to increase more than the cost of inflation for the next three years following the Open," Mr. Parks said. The daily fee for the Black Course is $31 during the week and $39 on weekends; the other four courses cost $24 and $29. 
The clubhouse, which is on the state's Register of Historic Places, was also a factor in bringing the Open to Bethpage, said Bernadette Castro, state commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. "The U.S.G.A. was concerned about the clubhouse, if we'd look good and how we could serve everyone," she said. 
Steven Carl, owner of Carlyle on the Green, the park's food and beverage concessionaire since 1998, had a key role in the renovation of the building. Mr. Carl, who renovated the historic Oheka Castle catering hall in Cold Spring Hills in the early 1990's, worked with the Port Washington interior designer Beth Donner and the Hempstead architect Michael Russo in designing the renovation and the addition. 
Mr. Carl, who has a 20-year contract to run the concessions, invested $10 million in the project, which included constructing the grand ballroom and tripling the size of the pro shop to approximately 1,000 square feet. Global Golf, the pro shop concessionaire, invested $3 million in its renovation. 
The clubhouse was built in the 1920's for what was then the Lenox Hills Country Club, owned by Benjamin Franklin Yoakum, a railroad executive. The original course is now known as the Green Course.
After Mr. Yoakum's death, the state purchased the 1,500-acre property in 1932 and renamed it the Bethpage Golf Club. In the early 1940's it was redesigned with four additional 18-hole courses, including the Black, by a renowned golf course architect, A. W. Tillinghast.
By the time Mr. Carl came on the scene, the rambling 63,000-square-foot brick and cedar-shake clubhouse had begun to show its age. "The building had great bones," Mr. Carl said. "It had been left in disrepair all these years, but was in the style of an English manor house. I had to find a way to reposition all the spaces."
IN doing so, the pro shop and registration area, which had been in the central section of the building, were relocated to the north wing near Mr. Carl's new full-service 150-seat Oak Room Restaurant, which had been the site of a breakfast cafeteria. 
A reception area and lounge were created in the central section, where the original wide pegged-wood floors were polished and left intact, as were the 30-foot vaulted, beamed ceilings. The conservatory-style ballroom, with seating for more than 550 and a 2,000-square-foot dance floor, was constructed to the rear of the lounge, overlooking the first hole of the Black Course. 
The ballroom is surrounded on three sides by 24 sets of twin floor-length multipaned windows framed by cream-colored swagged drapes. Eight alabaster chandeliers hang from a coffered ceiling designed to provide excellent acoustics. The floor is of variegated Brazilian wood with a custom inlaid trim.
Two brick outdoor patios, which seat 300 people, border one side of the ballroom and the Oak Room, facing the Black Course.
The renovation also added a cocktail lounge and small dining areas. The clubhouse's long hallways have ornately framed prints with early 1900's themes and burgundy and green floral carpets on polished wood floors.
On the grounds, the 78 corporate tents, either 30 by 30 feet or 40 by 40, have been erected in three places on the Red or Green Courses, which are adjacent to the Black. Prices for the tents, which include 60 to 125 weekly tickets, are from $75,000 to $175,000 depending on tent size and location. 
In addition, there are 67 tables in two locations, which include meals and 12 tickets each. Tables are $40,000 for the week in the clubhouse and $30,000 in the 24,000-square-foot "champion's tent" adjacent to the 18th hole. 
According to Mimi S. Griffin, owner of MSG Productions of Bethlehem, Pa., which is running the corporate tents and tables, about 65 percent of the companies that are renting them are from the New York City area. Most of the remaining renters are from Texas, California, Britain and Japan. 
Including tickets that go to the corporations renting tents and tables, there are 42,500 tickets for the event. They sell for $275 for a weekly ticket and $35 a day for the three practice rounds and $65 a day for the tournament rounds.
Hotel occupancy for western Long Island's 10,000 hotel rooms should be at 100 percent for the week of the Open, said Robert Lipper, president of Island-Metro Publications, which publishes the Long Island Lodging Guide quarterly and tracks the Long Island hotel industry.
Last June, that region, extending from the Queens line to Riverhead in Suffolk County, had a 77 percent occupancy rate. "The week of the Open should bump us up to 85 percent for this June," he said. "There are very few rooms left on Long Island for that week and now they are pushing into Queens."
The golf event could be a positive catalyst for the industry, which has had a decline in occupancy rates over the past year. 
Last year, one hotel with 130 rooms was added to the Western Long Island region, and 306 rooms have become available so far this year in two new hotels. The first quarter occupancy rate for western Long Island was only 63 percent, down from 68 percent a year earlier. An additional 416 rooms are expected to open in May and another 50 this summer, Mr. Lipper said.
Up to 1,500 rooms have been booked by the golf association for its staff, players and members of the media, Mr. Parks said. 
Marie J. Kupfer, owner of the Hilton Huntington, which is about one mile from Bethpage State Park, said 75 percent of the Hilton's 300 rooms have been booked by the group and the remaining by local corporations. The rooms, which average $200 a night, have been booked for the Open's four-day period for three years, she said.
"This will be a huge boost" to the hotel industry, Ms. Kupfer said. "This is not just a matter of a week of filled rooms. There is a huge amount of energy connected to this."
The Garden City Hotel, which is 10 miles from the golf course, has been fully booked for the Open since last June, according to Brian Rosenberg, a vice president. The 372 rooms range from $375 a night for a single room to $2,700 for a penthouse suite.
While the majority of out-of-towners attending the Open are expected to stay at hotels, others had been expected to rent private homes. Long Island residents willing to rent their house for the event were asked to contact the Open management and provide information about their houses that could be forwarded to those who requested house rentals.
"A few players prefer to stay in private houses, but there is not the demand that people expected," said Jon Barker, manager of the Open. "Most of the ticket holders are day-trippers and of those who stay longer, 99 percent are at the hotels," he said.
Teri Catapano Black, owner of Century 21 Metro Realty in Bethpage, said: "We have received a tremendous amount of calls from people willing to rent their houses. But until now we have not placed anyone that was interested."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven Carl and Bernadette Castro at the renovated clubhouse. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times) Map of Long Island highlights Bethpage State Park.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Media-Savvy Campaign Promotes Living in 2 Towns

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
WHY does the value of real estate in one community rise much faster than the value of property in a nearby town?
 Certainly, there are very literal answers to the question, as South Orange and Maplewood -- two towns that market themselves as one -- discovered six years ago when the Midtown Direct train line to Manhattan was installed. Cutting about 30 minutes off a commute is a direct route to improving property values, and they have risen more than 10 percent a year in the last three years. 
 But the more ethereal factor of reputation -- the "buzz" a town generates -- also figures into property values. A town like Montclair, which is home to a remarkable number of people who work for media companies, has long had the buzz factor in its favor; South Orange/Maplewood, right next door to Newark, which was a racial battleground in the 1960's, traditionally has not. 
But now a group of committed and sophisticated citizens has coalesced in South Orange/Maplewood -- many of whom arrived with the advent of the Midtown Direct -- and a campaign is under way to change all that.
A grassroots organization, called the South Orange/Maplewood Community Coalition, was set up in 1996, financed by grants and private donations. While the organization was new, a number of its members had been active in other community groups over the years, including one established after the Newark riots whose main focus was in preventing white flight and promoting diversity. In 1997, the new group adopted the strategy of making the two communities -- which were once literally one and which currently share a school system -- become one for marketing purposes. Over the years, coalition members have developed all sorts of strategies to improve buildings and neighborhoods; now they are mounting a concerted effort to get their two-town hometown some good press. 
"We are looking to make people who could be potential move-ins aware of the lifestyle our community offers," said Ellen Greenfield, chairwoman of the coalition's Marketing and Public Relations Committee. "One of the ways we do that is by giving personal tours to people who are thinking of moving here. Another way is by advertising in newspapers around the tristate region.
"Another way is by trying to place stories about the beautiful homes here and various projects going on with the media."
Several weeks ago, Jacqueline Herships of South Orange, who is paid by the coalition to do part-time media relations work, set up a daylong media tour. A handful of writers and journalists were furnished with prefab article ideas, introductions to the people involved and even suggestions as to which publications might be interested.
Early indications are the effort will pay off: This Old House magazine is interested in an article about a battered, renovation-corrupted Victorian home -- and its barn near collapse -- that are being fully restored by new owners in Maplewood, Ms. Herships said. "It's the kind of exposure that could raise interest all around the country in the unique homes and village feeling that are available here," she said. 
On the tour, writers were also introduced to Cynthia and William Marshall, Maplewood residents who are 18th century art and antiques experts and offer themselves as quotable authorities. Les Saisons, a lone exception to the rule against bed-and-breakfasts in Maplewood, was shown and suggested as a vehicle for reporting on the issue of whether such establishments strengthen or hurt a community's cohesiveness. A South Orange architect discussed deck, landing, porch and renovation projects he has built in both towns. And two homes and gardens in the Montrose Park Historic District of South Orange were on display.
Ms. Herships had met with some "placement" successes even before the tour. Articles written in response to her suggestions or with her help as a source of information include a piece in the February issue of Victorian Homes magazine about Montrose Park and another previously in Victorian Decorating Ideas; articles in The New York Times and The Star-Ledger about the influx of artists in the community and the new performing arts center going up in South Orange; and an article in New Jersey Business News on how promoting the arts in the two towns has helped spur economic development.
But why are coalition members convinced such press notices are tied to property values? "We have seen how it works so far," Ms. Herships said, "with artists moving in from New York, and so many people from Brooklyn -- it seems like every other person is from Brooklyn -- and then they tell their friends about our community, and then they move in, and tell their friends. Word of mouth has helped change neighborhoods that were rundown and totally undervalued for 30 years after the Newark riots into lovely, thriving neighborhoods.
"Getting stories published is just a stronger, more effective form of word of mouth."
Several years ago, the coalition decided it needed a reading on what the trend is in property values in South Orange/Maplewood compared with other towns. So one coalition member, George Robinson, a retired telephone company manager, conducted a study. He did not take just an average of sales prices, figuring the sale of a single mansion can set that number askew. Instead, he took the assessed value of properties for tax purposes -- which remains unchanged for about 10 years in most towns -- and compared that with sales prices, coming up with a ratio that tells if market value is rising or falling.
"Maplewood and South Orange have done extremely well over the last few years," Mr. Robinson concluded.
Last year, according to his findings for 12 towns in the area, Maplewood's values rose 15.5 percent from the year before, more than any other town studied, and South Orange's property values increased 11.7 percent. In 2000, South Orange topped the list with a 22.7 percent rise, followed closely by Montclair's 22.4 percent increase, and Maplewood came in third with a 19.4 percent increase. Ms. Herships noted that there are a variety of types of neighborhoods in South Orange/Maplewood, and so she pitches stories to all sorts of publications.
Right now, Ms. Herships said the Hilton neighborhood in Maplewood, a niche for smaller homes and bungalows, is popular with single home buyers and younger couples. Those who yearn for a grand Victorian or a historic home that needs work are attracted to South Orange, she said.
David Gassman, who said he is in semiretirement after teaching European and medieval history at the Hudson Valley Center of Empire State College in Hartsdale, N.Y., has lived in an 1869 home on Irving Avenue for 18 years and has been refurbishing it all that time. Chairman of the South Orange Historical and Preservation Society, he spoke of an "unbelievably rich architectural heritage" in his town -- and noted that restoration of its public buildings contributes to the value of its neighborhoods.
THE historic Village Hall has been written about in several architecture publications, Mr. Gassman said. The castlelike fire house has become a well-maintained favorite as well, he said, and the town Community Center was recently repainted in appropriate Victorian colors.
Mr. Gassman was part of a group of residents who helped save the Old Stone House five years ago. Currently a ramshackle-looking place, the structure near the South Orange train station contains within it a pre-1680 Dutch home that is the second-oldest building in New Jersey. A group of residents are now pursuing grants to restore the building and locate a furniture museum there. 
"This might sound funny," said Jason Marshall -- the son of the antiques experts on the media tour and the one who conceived the museum idea -- "but we need the right kind of people to move here, people who will be excited about such things. Referring to Ms. Herships, he added: "That's why promoting the towns the way Jackie does works out so well. It brings in people who can respond to the true value of the buildings and homes that have been here all along."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A map on May 5 with an article in some regional copies about a campaign to promote living in South Orange and Maplewood, N.J., misidentified a town adjoining South Orange to the north. It is West Orange, not East Orange.

HEADLINE: Milford Academy Hopes for a Comeback 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH BEST 

 BODY:
LIKE the students who seek its help in overcoming missed opportunities, Milford Academy just wants another chance to succeed.
 Founded in 1916 to help students prepare for their entrance to Yale University, Milford Academy has become a finishing school of sorts for talented athletes trying to win college scholarships in football and basketball at Division I schools, the highest level of competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The academy's students, most of whom are from outside of Connecticut, have completed high school but need to work on fulfilling basic courses required under N.C.A.A. eligibility rules. They also try to improve their test scores for the two standardized college entrance tests, the SAT or ACT. 
 In recent years Milford Academy has struggled to keep its doors open. 
On Thursday, Mayor James L. Richetelli Jr. of Milford announced that the city would buy the 20-acre Milford Academy campus for $2.2 million, which would be raised through a bond issue. Under the proposed terms of the agreement, the school would have a two-year grace period to complete scheduled repairs and to reorganize its finances before beginning to pay an annual rent of about $135,000. The lease could be renewed in five-year increments, the mayor said.
The proposal is subject to approval by the city's Board of Aldermen, but several aldermen seemed to indicate support for the plan. In 1999 the city paid $2.8 million for other Milford Academy property, including an indoor swimming pool, a soccer field and another two acres of land.
The mayor said the city should acquire the property to prevent development of the land, a concern for residents in the adjacent neighborhood. "This agreement is very important for the city," Mr. Richetelli said. "It will ensure that the land remains as it is." 
The mayor also said the continued existence of the school would ensure that the economic impact of Milford Academy would expand. Much of the school's $750,000 annual budget is spent locally, using vendors and other services. The school has struggled through a publicized battle between its board of trustees and its former headmaster of 10 years, Dino F. Ciaburri, who recently filed a breach of contract suit against the board seeking about $250,000 in back pay and damage to his reputation.
The administrators trying to repair the school's finances and image point to the 310 municipal code violations, poor housing conditions, neglected repairs and other difficulties that led to Mr. Ciaburri's resignation last July. The school plans to repay a previous $800,000 loan made by one of its trustees, Joseph Kelly, as well as to make repairs on the campus and to pay off other debts, he added. Mr. Kelly had earlier asked for repayment of the loan.
Administrators at Milford Academy are trying to look ahead even as they try to put their problems in the past. A hearing on the suit by Mr. Ciaburri is scheduled for tomorrow in Derby Superior Court, postponed from last week after Milford Academy filed a countersuit against the former headmaster claiming that he improperly managed the school and its finances. The former headmaster's lawyer, David Pite, said he would show that Mr. Ciaburri did an excellent job of running the school under a very difficult situation. 
Southern Connecticut Gas Company is also seeking payment from the school for a disputed gas bill. The company claims it is owed $60,000, while the school says it owes only about half that amount. A hearing is set for tomorrow on that claim, Mr. Coffey said.
William Chaplick, the Milford Academy football coach who replaced Mr. Ciaburri as the school's chief administrator, said he is determined to keep the school open to keep giving a second chance to talented athletes. He said he is optimistic that Milford Academy will overcome its most difficult battle.
"When I took over, everything was closed off except for the electricity," Mr. Chaplick said. "We're better this year than we were last year. We stopped the free fall. I think we're alive and kicking." 
A recent visit to Milford Academy's campus found work under way for renovations to the gymnasium, a library room filled with reference and textbooks, and a small, tidy cafeteria for student meals. This contrasts sharply with reports from the parents of former students about conditions at the school only last year that were described as a mother's nightmare. 
"It went beyond what you would consider code violations," said Joanne Heslin Lavery, a Hartford lawyer whose son, John, is now playing football at Northeastern University. "There were trash and debris all over the floors in the halls. The shower stalls were black with mold and there was broken furniture. It was as disgusting as you can imagine." 
Despite its problems, Milford Academy has managed to move its students toward college scholarships. Playing a schedule against college junior varsity squads like those from the Naval Academy and Bucknell University, the football team this year won eight of 10 games, and the basketball team finished with a 37-5 record. 
Football players at Milford Academy typically spend one semester at the school, taking classes and playing against other teams before heading off to college. Because their season crosses both semesters, basketball players spend a full academic year in school. Football players pay $13,500 for room, board and tuition, while basketball players pay $19,500. 
Milford Academy students spend classroom time completing any missing core course requirements to become eligible for the N.C.A.A.. Those requirements include four years of English, two years of mathematics, two years of science, two years of social studies, two additional core units and one additional year of English, math or science. Students also work to meet the minimum standardized test requirements of a total SAT score of 820 or a total ACT score of 68.
During the current school year, Milford Academy's football and basketball players won $2.5 million in athletic scholarships to colleges and universities, including Syracuse, Brown, Purdue, Tulane, Vanderbilt and Boston College, said William Chaplick, the Milford Academy football coach who replaced Mr. Ciaburri as the school's chief administrator.
There are 55 football players and 15 basketball players committed to attending Milford Academy in the fall, said Mr. Chaplick. His goal is to recruit 10 to 15 more football players for the coming year.
"Nobody comes to Milford Academy if they did what they were supposed to do in high school," Mr. Chaplick said. "The glue that brings them together is they all had problems. There's some reason they're here." 
In some cases, the students need to mature both academically and athletically. Instead of using two years of N.C.A.A. eligibility at a junior college, they can attend Milford Academy and still play for up to four years in college. 
"It gave me a year to get physically stronger, which a lot of coaches who were recruiting me told me," said Kason Mims, a basketball player who graduated from Christ the King High School in Queens, N.Y., (the same school attended by University of Connecticut star Sue Bird) before enrolling at Milford Academy for a year. Now a sophomore guard for Quinnipiac University, which played for the Northeast Conference championship this year, he improved his SAT scores while in Milford and is on schedule to graduate with a degree in mass communications.
Milford Academy's football players have gone on to great success, according to the school's promotional materials. During the last year, 13 former Falcons appeared in college bowl games. Nine graduates played in the National Football League last year, including the defensive end Frank Ferrara of the New York Giants. Those successes continue to draw athletes like the linebacker Cleophus Harbison of Nashville to Milford. Scheduled to go to Hofstra University to play football, he said Milford Academy had helped him to focus on his studies; something he admits he did not do in high school.
"I went to school every day, but I just wasn't paying attention," Mr. Harbison said. "It's one-on-one here. It's a chance to start over."

HEADLINE: Truckers Warn State On Fees 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
AS the state treasurer continues to nibble around the edges of the state budget, the trucking companies in New Jersey are getting indigestion.
 What had Gail Toth, executive director of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, so riled last week was a plan for an incremental increase in truck registration fees, among other things, causing truckers to warn that the added cost could hurt businesses still reeling from last year's economic downturn. 
 "We recognize that we are dealing with a budget deficit, but the trucking industry has been hit so severely from several different angles," said Ms. Toth, whose organization represents about 1,000 trucking companies that operate in New Jersey. 
The changes being proposed by John E. McCormac, the state treasurer and one of the people who has Governor McGreevey's ear as the state wrestles with a $5.3 billion deficit, would add another cost for companies already contending with sharp increases in insurance rates and fuel costs.
The state plans to increase the annual registration fee for big trucks to an average of $1,260 from the current rate of $1,100, Ms. Toth said. The increase might not seem like much, but Ms. Toth said most trucking firms were operating on razor-thin profit margins and were ill-positioned to accept any extra costs.
Matthew Wright, chief executive of Apgar Bros. Inc., a midsized trucking company in Bound Brook, said businesses like his had been hit with steep increases in insurance premiums in the last year.
The increase in registration fees, Mr. Wright said, "would be one more brick on the pile."
"The trucking industry is a tough business, and it is especially tough now," said Mr. Wright, whose 90 tractors carry construction material throughout the state. "In the last 24 months, we have absorbed some astronomical fuel hikes and we have absorbed some enormous toll increases from the Port Authority."
Martin M. Robins, director of the Transportation Policy Institute at the Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center at Rutgers University, agreed that business had been tough for truckersin the last year.
"There has been a serious cost squeeze in the industry relating to insurance and fuel," Mr Robins said.
He said that the cargo industry -- including trucking and warehouse companies -- had become a crucial part of the state's economy and that New Jersey's ports and rail yards, coupled with the state's proximity to New York, had made the state a major "distribution and logistics center for the Northeast and the entire country."
For their part, state budget officials say they are trying to raise money to make up the budget gap by raising fees in areas that can bear the costs. 
"The rationale is that heavy damage to New Jersey roadways are attributable to heavy trucks," said Tom Vincz, a spokesman for the Treasury Department. "This is a way to offset costs of road upkeep and maintenance."
Mr. Vincz said that even with an increase, the registration fee would still be lower than in most surrounding states. The average fee for trucks in Pennsylvania trucks is $1,867 and in Delaware it is $1,280. New York State is slightly lower, at $1,198.
"Obviously, the increase would raise New Jersey's average as well, but we are still in competitive status with neighboring states," he said.
Trucking companies are also concerned about proposals to change the corporate tax to reflect total sales -- known as gross receipts -- rather than profits. Because trucking companies operate high-volume, low-profit businesses, they fear that the change could pose a serious problem.
"We are making two cents on the dollar," said Ms. Toth. "If we were taxed on gross receipts we would be out of business."
Mr. Vincz said the treasury department was aware that a gross receipts tax could hurt low-profit businesses and that Mr. McCormac was trying to tailor the proposal "in a way that recognizes the economic realities of narrow-margin, high-volume companies such as retailers and supermarkets."
Still, truckers insisted that the immediate costs would be borne by the freight haulers and warehouse companies that operate in New Jersey, but that in the long run they would be passed along to consumers.
"We are all going to be paying for it at the cash register," Ms. Toth said.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Apartment Building at 101 West End Ave.; 
A REIT Buys In Manhattan

 BODY:
The twin-towered 506-apartment building at 101 West End Avenue has been purchased by the Archstone-Smith real estate investment trust in what the purchaser said was the first acquisition of a Manhattan residential building by a REIT. The Denver-based REIT announced last week that it had bought the building, completed in May 2000, between 64th and 65th Streets, from Tishman Speyer Properties of Manhattan for $209 million. 
 Monthly rents for the studios and one- and two-bedroom apartments range from $2,350 to $8,590 a month, according to Archstone-Smith. 
 Although the Manhattan market is difficult to penetrate, said R. Scot Sellers, the REIT's chief executive, New York City has a high proportion of renters "due to extremely high housing costs, which makes the market even more attractive to apartment owners." 
Although such REIT's as AvalonBay Communities and Post Properties have built in New York in recent years, investment by REIT's in the city remains unusual. "The reason we do not see more residential REIT's in New York," said Michael Schill, director of the Furman Center of Real Estate and Urban Policy at N.Y.U., "is because our apartments tend to be either family owned or owned for the long haul as investments, not as a commodity to be bought and sold in response to market opportunities."

HEADLINE: Race, Writ Large 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
THIS is the renaissance?
 Pockmarked row houses. Sneering drug dealers. Trash that seems to sit by the curb for who knows how long. Then there was the matter of the people who chose to use the vacant lot next to H. David Archer's house as a bathroom. 
 "It was really bad," said Mr. Archer, 42, recalling the day four years ago when he moved to a beleaguered stretch of this city's South Ward. "But I heard -- not saw, heard -- so much about the renaissance, that Newark is on its way back up, that I said I can kind of suffer through whatever until it gets better. But it didn't get better."
This is the renaissance. A world-class performing arts center. A new minor-league baseball stadium, long-overdue downtown improvements and the sense that Ike Thomas's beloved city is moving away from being the punch line of bad jokes about urban America. 
"People who've just come here don't see what it was; they just see what it is now," said Mr. Thomas, 70, a wily veteran of the ward politics and grass-roots skirmishes of another time. "People don't see the progress we've made, they don't see how far we've come."
The question of how far Newark has come is at the heart of the most spirited mayoral race here in decades: the down-to-the-wire contest between the four-term incumbent, Mayor Sharpe James, and the thirtysomething challenger, City Councilman Cory Booker. In short, it is the classic political paradigm of the old guard versus the new wave.
Still, in this campaign, political experts say, there is a significant difference. The outcome of the nonpartisan election on May 14 hinges, of course, on how voters view the candidates when it comes to matters of money, education, personal style and home address. But this race -- between two black men whose styles both take up a lot of space -- will just as likely turn on the prickly dynamics of intraracial politics.
And amid -- or despite -- the swirl of charges being unleashed by the two camps, a telling glimpse is emerging of the evolution of black political power and the changing face of a Newark, a city of 274,000 residents that is about 53 percent black.
To be sure, the ethnic and generational issues that have emerged are not entirely new. A similar scenario unfolded in 1994 in the unsuccessful effort by Adam Clayton Powell 4th to unseat Representative Charles B. Rangel, more than 30 years his senior. And more recently in Detroit, 31-year-old Kwame Kilpatrick defeated Gill Hill, 69, in last year's election. Still, the personalities here bring their own sharp differences to the table.
There is Mr. James, 66, a product of the segregated South who became a political power broker in his adopted city amid the tumult of a new and in many ways overwhelming era for poor blacks trying to survive in a burned-out, depopulated and cash-starved Newark. And there is Mr. Booker, who at 32 -- with a Bergen County background, Ivy League pedigree and a campaign well financed by blacks and whites from within Newark and outside the state -- represents the fulfillment of much that Mr. James's generation fought for.
"What we have here is an old scenario that has played out over the last century in ethnic politics," said Clement A. Price, a professor of history at Rutgers University-Newark who is a longtime observer of city politics. "But there is an interesting twist to it. In many ways, it's the incumbent versus the fair-haired boy, writ black, if you will."
And it is rife with the complexities of an internal ethnic dynamic that scholars say both candidates have tried to exploit.
Mayor James, a foot soldier in Newark's civil rights movement, is very much a product of the ethnic-based politics of his era. "Sharpe James grew up in a time defined by racial tension," Professor Price said. "He came up in an era when ethnic politics pervaded Newark politics, which means that Sharpe James and his generation cohorts speak directly and almost exclusively to the black community."
For his part, Mr. Booker was reared in the aftermath of the early civil rights struggle -- the beneficiary of a generation that took to heart Dr. King's exhortation to judge people by the content of their character rather than the color of their skin -- largely forsaking the old African-American guard and instead building a broad base of multiracial support.
"He's taking advantage of the new realities of Newark," Professor Price said. "There's less emphasis on race, greater reliance on government, less reliance on black political power, more reliance on cobbling together a coalition of the disgruntled."
Considering this city's shifting demographics, such a strategy does not seem unwise on its face. Although Newark, like most large, old industrial cities, saw an overall decline in population in the 1990's, figures from the 2000 Census show that the most drastic gains were among those who described themselves as Hispanic or some other race. However, it is not clear whether this will help Mr. Booker.
In recent years, Latino voters have tended the follow the lead of established community leaders, and so far, most of them are backing Mr. James.
If recent census trends are any indication, their numbers may continue to grow. Indeed, residents here who described themselves as Hispanic rose from just over a quarter of the city's population in 1990 to nearly a third in 2000. At the same time, the percentage of blacks who live in Newark decreased by about 5 percentage points. While the city's political power structure is still overwhelmingly black, observers question how much the old ethnic political rules will apply in an evolving Newark.
"This election will see to what extent the multiplicity of ethnicities in Newark respond to a Sharpe James, who still stands largely as a black leader, versus a Cory Booker, who speaks to a multiracial completion of the renaissance in Newark," Professor Price said.

Waiting for More Changes
Seeing that renaissance come to fruition is not lost on residents like Mr. Archer, who has owned a house in the Weequahic section of the South Ward for four years. He views the election as pivotal in attracting and keeping new residents.
"Newark is losing good people because of all this nonsense we've had all these years," said Mr. Archer, who with his wife, Nicole, was drawn here from nearby Belleville because of its reasonable housing prices. Besides, he remembers the real estate agent telling him that he would be living only a few blocks from the mayor.
Mr. Archer, an account administrator for a medical device company, was impressed with the changes he saw in downtown Newark, and he foresaw the promise of more progress in the South Ward. He jumped at the chance to be part of a resurgent Newark, and waited patiently during those first couple of years for change.
He is still waiting -- although no longer so patiently. "It's still a slum," he said, the sadness and regret in his voice tinged with the soft lilt of his native Barbados. "Any way you describe that, I live in a slum. I live as a prisoner in my own home. And it's just not fair to us."
Mr. Archer could not care less about the questions of race and class that the campaign has unleashed. He just wants to be able to walk to the corner store without being hassled by drug dealers.
It would be bad enough if it were just the dealers. Or the car thieves who kept breaking into a neighbor's Nissan Maxima, pushing up her insurance premiums and pushing her off the block. Or the lack of adequate trash pickup. Or what he considers slow response times by the police.
Most galling, however, are the small, everyday upheavals in Mr. Archer's quality of life -- like the people who took to using an overgrown lot next door as their own open-air outhouse.
"There were people defecating in that lot," Mr. Archer said. "It was disgusting."
After years of complaining, Mr. Archer went to Home Depot, picked up a few lawn and cleaning supplies and quietly went about reclaiming the lot. "I just bought a sickle and went to work," Mr. Archer said."
He sees Mr. Booker as a like-minded agent of change, and was so moved by the candidate that he has been a campaign volunteer for several weeks. Mr. Archer's participation in the campaign is all the more striking because as a non-citizen, he is not allowed to vote.
"That's part of the reason I'm working so hard," said Mr. Archer, who explained that he was motivated to begin filing citizenship papers by Mr. Booker's campaign. For now, his wife carries political conviction enough for both of them to the ballot box.
"I firmly believe Cory Booker will make serious changes," Mr. Archer said. "He is young, he is sharp, he is aggressive."
And if he does not follow through? "I'll be out in the streets handing out fliers for another guy," Mr. Archer said.
For now, the question remains: Will Mr. Booker's perceived message -- and his courting of a variegated constituency -- be viewed as an attempt to distance himself from black Newark?
By his own estimate, Mr. Booker has raised about half of his $3 million campaign war chest -- almost unheard of in Newark politics -- from far away as Arkansas and California. He has been praised by the likes of George F. Will and Barbra Streisand. The Economist, a weekly British magazine read widely by this country's intelligentsia, called him "Al Gore with personality."
If nothing else, the councilman's media-friendly image and high-profile supporters may prove especially beneficial in a city where residents still seem stung about having been the butt of jokes by late-night talk show hosts 20 years ago.
"This may really work to Booker's favor," said David Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University. "If voters see Booker as something of a celebrity and being supported by social notables, they might say, 'This guy is a big-time player and that's what Newark needs.' "
Just as easily, however, Mr. Booker's affiliation with those outside Newark -- especially white supporters -- may backfire when black voters head to the polls.
"Some people see him as a tool of outside influence, and Sharpe James has played that card," Professor Price said. "James is trying to say that Cory Booker is trying to take advantage of the hard work he and his generation have done."
As a product of suburban Bergen County, Mr. Booker also has to win over those residents here who are dubious about how much he can identify with the black experience in urban America, a world of poverty, crime, drugs and untreated disease.
"As black people, we have our own notions of racial authenticity," said Professor Price. "Cory Booker, because he has pedigree, because he came from the suburbs and because he's generating white support, he's being portrayed as if not nonblack, he's unblack."
That message, the professor said, might even be not so subtly reflected in campaign advertisements -- and even in Mr. James's slogan, in which the mayor proclaims that he is "The Real Deal."
Perhaps sensitive to his suburban background and elite education, Mr. Booker has made several well-publicized, attempts to interact with residents at ground level since he arrived on the city's political scene six years ago. He has staged hunger strikes for increased police patrols, lived in a trailer on some of the city's most notorious street corners and now lives at Brick Towers, a public housing development.
While seen as an example of Mr. Booker's common touch by those outside the city, the moves have drawn a mixed reaction from Newark residents and are viewed alternately as either well-intentioned gestures by the councilman or contrived media stunts.

Some Say Booker Must Wait
Mr. Thomas, the 74-year-old longtime ward politician, chooses the latter. He has worked in the trenches of the city's civil rights movement with the likes of Kenneth Gibson and a gap-toothed, fast-talking community organizer from the South Ward, by way of Florida, named Sharpe James.
Mr. Thomas's generation, using a combination of sheer will, high energy and personal charisma, roused a sometimes passive electorate and built the foundation for today's black political power structure.
It was leaders like Mr. Gibson and Mr. James who aggressively fought the white establishment and seized the city's political reins when whites fled the city after the searing riots of 1967. After watching Mr. Gibson become Newark's first black mayor in 1970 and Mr. James ascend to the same post 16 years later, Mr. Thomas enjoyed a political career with his own share of firsts -- first black to lead the parking authority, first black to help lead a local sewer commission. Indeed, today he himself is something of an eminence gris among the city's political establishment.
Yes, Mr. Thomas concedes, Mr. Booker is in many ways the political progeny of the movement he and his peers helped begin. And, yes, he said, someday, somewhere, Mr. Booker may make a fine civic leader.
But, Mr. Thomas said, that day is not now and that place is not Newark. Mr. Thomas said that he did not support Mr. Booker because he feared that the councilman was an opportunist. Like many voters, Mr. Thomas was concerned that if elected, Mr. Booker would look to make his political mark in Newark before moving on to greater heights.
Besides that, Mr. Thomas said, Mr. Booker simply has not put enough time into working in the modern-day political trenches that the Kenneth Gibsons toiled in during the 1960's.
"If it was someone who has gone through some of the trials we've had over the years, I would be supportive of them," Mr. Thomas said. "But he hasn't paid his dues."
He is also suspicious of the intense support that Mr. Booker has drawn from whites, as well as those outside the city.
"When you make an investment," Mr. Thomas said, "you want a return on that investment. And if Caucasians can come up with these kinds of funds to support the campaign, they're going to come look for a return on that investment."
What might that return be? Gentrification of the city that displaces longtime residents after a long struggle to regain respectability? The installation of a more Republican agenda in City Hall? A reversal of the political gains blacks have made over the past 30 years?
Mr. Thomas is not sure, but he is certain that a Mayor Booker would not auger well for residents here. "People are suspicious that he doesn't have the best interests, not only of the black community, but of the full constituency at heart," Mr. Thomas said.
And while he acknowledges that there is still much more to be done, and that there are pockets of the city where urban ills persist, Mr. Thomas believes that the rebirth of Newark is real.
"And a lot of that starts with Sharpe James," he said.

Newark's Rebound Is Questioned
To be sure, Mayor James has to overcome his own chorus of skeptics. The 32-year veteran of local politics must convince voters that he has not become the kind of complacent figurehead of the political establishment that he railed against as a community activist.
Many voters here question the viability of the city's rebound and wonder whether the outlying neighborhoods will become as vibrant as the reborn downtown. Mr. Booker has emphasized "a renaissance for the rest of us" in his campaign and argues that Mr. James should have moved the city further during his 16 years in office.
The mayor's critics point out that many residents remain mired in stunning poverty, that not enough progress has been made reducing crime and that problems with the city's woeful public schools are as intractable as ever.
Not only that, but Mr. James is also seen by many here as the gloved hand turning the wheel of this city's vast political machine, which has been working double time to try to turn back the most serious threat to the city's entrenched powers in a generation.
And all that does not begin to address the accusations leveled at Mr. James by Mr. Booker -- that the mayor's supporters have been behind a spate of pre-election dirty tricks: campaign office break-ins, the mass removal of pro-Booker posters -- charges the mayor vehemently denies.
Then there was the dust-up over the Sights social club, which was closed in March for what the police said was promoting prostitution. An aide to Mr. Booker who was waiting outside the club had been singled out in a police department press release, even though he had not been arrested or charged.
Mayor James noted that he would have fired any aide who engaged in similar conduct, only to face statements by the club's manager that the mayor had himself been to the club twice. After initially refusing to say whether he had visited to the club, the mayor acknowledged that he had been there during a police raid, acting as "the closing-down official, observing wrongdoing and closing down."
To Wil R. Sherman, there is something more than a little familiar about the Newark mayor's race, 2002 edition.
"Newark is on its way back, Newark is on its way back," Mr. Sherman, a 70-year-old South Ward resident, said recently. "I've been hearing the same thing every four years. When is it going to get back?"
With the election little more than a week away, Mr. Sherman has not decided for whom he's going to vote.
His neighbors are fond of extolling the pros and cons of each candidate, he said.
Of Mr. Booker, Mr. Sherman said: "He's good. A lot of people say, 'Let's give it to the young man and see what he can do.' "
Of Mr. James, Mr. Sherman said: "What James has going for him is that he has been in this mess. People know what he's about."
But still, Mr. Sherman said, his question remains unanswered: When is Newark going to get back?
"I honestly think the best man for the city hasn't run yet," Mr. Sherman said. "Either that, or he hasn't been born."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
The Family Business

BYLINE:  By WENDY GINSBERG 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
STANDING in front of a heap of reporters, Assemblywoman Bonnie Watson Coleman didn't say a word.
 Instead, she simply stood behind various department commissioners who were detailing Governor McGreevey's new early retirement program as her eyes searched the room. 
 Her glance locked with those of people she recognized, and with innate political know-how she would offer an earnest smile and mouth, "Hi." It was enough to make the recipients of the intimate, low-key greeting feel a little more important than the person standing next to them.
Since her childhood, the 57-year-old Ms. Watson Coleman has been steeped in New Jersey's haphazard political culture. Her father, Assemblyman John S. Watson, a former six-term lawmaker, would lead political discussions at the dinner table. 
Earlier this year, Ms. Watson Coleman went on to try to fill her father's shoes -- and then some -- when she was selected by Democratic colleagues to head the Assembly Budget Committee and then take the reins of the State Democratic Committee.
"It was a natural evolution for me," Ms. Watson Coleman said. "I'm used to being a woman in a male-dominated world."
As head of the Democratic Committee, Ms. Watson Coleman is charged with increasing interest in the Democratic Party, and with finding people to contribute time and money. She is especially interested in attracting young people, minority members and women.
"I'm like the cheerleader for the Democrats," Ms. Watson Coleman said. "I have to be the most vociferous, the most active and the loudest in the party. It's my job to keep the party healthy and to reach out to new communities."
A Ewing resident, Ms. Watson Coleman has represented the 15th District in South Jersey since 1998. Born in Camden, she has lived in Moorestown, Trenton, East Orange, Orange, Newark and Nutley.
She began public service in 1966 with the Department of Public Safety's division of civil rights. In 1974, she started the transportation department's office of civil rights. Later she served as an assistant commissioner of community affairs under Gov. James Florio.
When Shirley K. Turner, an assemblywoman at the time, decided to run for State Senate, Ms. Watson Coleman ran to replace her.
During her years as an assemblywoman, Ms. Watson Coleman has pushed to extend urban enterprise zones and lower the sales tax in inner cities to rejuvenate struggling local economies.
"Bonnie cut her eyeteeth in politics," said Ms. Turner, who still holds the Senate seat from the 15th District. "Her father was a pioneer and a trailblazer. She's following in his footsteps."
While Ms. Watson Coleman's public career was on the ascendancy, however, her private life was suffering.
A first marriage to Jim Carter in 1972 -- they had a son -- ended in divorce in the early 1980's. She later married William Coleman, who had two sons from a previous marriage, in 1995. 
Then last November, two of Ms. Watson Coleman's sons -- William Carter-Watson, 21, and Jared C. Coleman, 19 -- pleaded guilty to first-degree armed robbery in the heist of a Kids "R" Us clothing store in the Mercer Mall last March, and now face up to seven years in prison.
"It's tough to learn such a lesson," said Ms. Watson Coleman, who has one other son, as her eyes filled with tears. 
Ms. Watson Coleman spent much of last year campaigning for Mr. McGreevey, who played a crucial role in her current appointments.
"Assemblywoman Watson Coleman has worked assiduously to provide clear direction for the party," Mr. McGreevey said in an interview. "She possesses a strong understanding of the legislative process and the issues of concern for New Jersey families."
Although the Democrats are currently enjoying their reign in Trenton, the Republican State Committee chairman, State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., said heading up any party is a lot of responsibility.
"Assemblywoman Watson Coleman is a good choice for that position," Mr. Kyrillos said. "But with success comes a lot of responsibility and expectation."
During her two-year term, which Ms. Watson Coleman began in February, she said, she hopes to convene discussions and local meetings as well as reach out on the Internet.
"At the end of my term I want there to be a demonstrable difference from when I began," Ms. Watson Coleman said. "I want people to see that I brought more people from more communities into active support of the party."
Ms. Watson Coleman is of average height, and her close-cropped haircut draws focus on the full cheeks that envelop her broad smile. It is rare when she is not wearing a fashionable business suit.
Her demeanor remains relaxed until she talks about the Democratic Party. Then she leans forward on her chair, talking intently of ways to increase the party's influence. It is a sample of what her brother noticed when he was her partner in a childhood card game called bid whist, which resembles bridge.
"She's very competitive," said her brother, Bill Watson. "You need to have a good relationship with your partner in that game, and, boy, can she intimidate her partner if they make the wrong move."
Despite her intensity, it was a shock when she told the family she wanted to run for the State Assembly.
"We all understood clearly from my father what you had to give up with a public life," her brother said. "It was a family decision for her to run. We knew she'd have to give up a lot of privacy."
Ms. Watson Coleman was not always so sure about entering public life.
"My father always wanted one of the four of us to go into politics," she said. "And I was the one who traveled with him and wrote his speeches when he was a legislator."
To be sure, she and her brothers were already serving the public. One brother is an administrator of the Green Acres program for the state Department of Environmental Protection, and another just moved from New Jersey Transit to head community relations for the transportation department.
A third brother, Bill Watson, three years younger than his sister, is director of the John S. Watson Institute for Public Policy at Edison State College. It was named for their father, who died in 1996 at age 72.
Despite her apprehension, Ms. Watson Coleman began campaigning in 1997, with her brother Bill as a top adviser. She won handily in a year when every incumbent remained in office and Republicans maintained the majority in both houses.
The tide turned last November when Jim McGreevey was elected governor. Ms. Watson Coleman, who had aggressively campaigned on Mr. McGreevey's behalf, had her named tossed about for various high-level positions, including secretary of state. By February, she was selected to head the New Jersey Democratic State Committee.
She already knew the neighborhood. After all, she met her current husband, William Watson, on the sidewalk in front of the State House at a traveling exhibition on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
She also maintains other offices on West State Street -- the one from which she heads the state committee, her Assembly office and her office for the Budget Committee.
So while she will always to some extent be linked to Trenton, her new title has forced her to focus beyond the capital.
"She's a tireless worker and very knowledgable about New Jersey," said the Assembly speaker, Albio Sires. "She is someone that can cross any line, and make people feel like they want to be in the Democratic Party."
Ms. Watson Coleman's legacy will rest on whether Mr. Sires is right.

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE; 
Not the Hamptons

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

 BODY:
IT has been a busy spring for Toby Fontaine.
 Despite the economic fluctuations of the past year, business has been brisk at her Bayberry Inn in Cape May. 
 And since Sept. 11, many of her newer customers have been escaping from a fall and winter of worry in New York and northern North Jersey.
"From what they tell me, it's because it is such a fight to get to the Hamptons," said Ms. Fontaine. "They say it's not as accessible. The traffic is bad. And they just find it friendlier here in South Jersey." 
Chatter among the Abercrombie set has it that the Hamptons is becoming so in that it's out, though most would be hard-pressed to find the statistics to back up that assertion. Still it is clear from conversations with real estate brokers and hotel and motel operators that there is movement in that direction.
"Price may be one thing, sure, but I think even rich people are getting tired of having to do the scene," said Jackie Kennedy, the rental manager at Diane Turton Realty in Spring Lake. "It's a pressure scene. You can't go out without getting dressed up.
Given the chance, Ms. Kennedy was only too happy to go on: "It's certainly gotten more expensive here, but the scene isn't like that. I mean, you don't dress up to go to Seaside Heights, certainly, or even Bay Head. And I think that is what a lot of people who used to go to the Hamptons are finding more comfortable here."
In Beach Haven, Pat Sepanak, the owner of Coldwell Banker Sand Dollar Real Estate, said that she too had noticed more and more New York license plates on Long Beach Island about three summers ago. This spring, however, she said that the calls and drop-ins had been coming from people who lived even farther away.
"Southern Connecticut, would you believe it?" said Ms. Sepanak. "That had never been a market for us before. You talk to these people and they say it's more of a hassle for them to go to the Hamptons than to cut down to the Garden State Parkway and come here."
"Then, she added, "those Connecticut people find they like the Jersey Shore better."
Ms. Sepanak put it this way.
"For one thing, it's beachier here, if you can use that term," she said, noting that no place on Long Beach Island, or most Jersey Shore communities, is more than a long walk to the beach -- forget about the considerable trek from the boardwalk to the surf in Wildwood. "At many places on Long Island, where the Hamptons are located, it is necessary to drive even from the tonier houses to the beach. If you have kids, you end up liking the idea that you can walk to the ocean."
But for every tale about a bigger and bigger and bigger crowd converging on the Jersey Shore, there are others to splash cold water on the theory.
For instance, Rich Donnelly, the owner of Donnelly Real Estate in Bay Head, said that he had not noticed high-end buyers changing their Hamptons view for Bay Head or Mantoloking.
"They are used to sprawling estates, and we just don't have that here, Mr. Donnelly said. "We may have things that rent for $40,000 or $50,000 a month, but they are just nice big houses on the beach, not many acres."
For her part, Ms. Kennedy of Spring Lake concurred.
"I get guys calling demanding, 'I make $4 million a year and I want this and that,' " she said in a mock New York accent. "But we don't have swimming pools and tennis courts and lots and lots of lawn. It's a different lifestyle. On the other hand, I think more and more people from New York are finding their way down here."
Certainly, New York money, which real estate agents say started making its way to the Jersey Shore more and more late 1990's, is reflected in prices all along the 127-mile coastline. In Stone Harbor, for instance, there were only two sales of more than $700,000 in 1995. During the past 18 months, however, the median sale in the town that shares a seven-mile island with Avalon -- usually the summer hangout of wealthy vacationers from Montgomery County outside Philadelphia -- is $807,500.
"Even now, though, it is far less expensive down here than in northern New Jersey and less expensive there than in the Hamptons," said Mark Grimes of Ocean City Realty, a few miles north of Stone Harbor. "I also think New Yorkers have trickled in because they can be both at a family resort and near Atlantic City. It is a different attraction than the Hamptons, but they seem to like the variety."
Another skeptic is Michele Caprio, the innkeeper at Conovers Bay Head Inn.
"If you are from Manhattan, you probably like the scene at the Hamptons and you will drive there no matter what," said Ms. Caprio. "The Jersey Shore isn't going to do it for you. I lived in Manhattan for 10 years and those people seem to want that action. But then, if you live on Staten Island, say, maybe this is more your scene. I like it, but it would be an odd change for people who love it out there to come to our little hamlet."
Still, Ms. Sepanak sees other evidence of the Hamptons coming to Long Beach Island -- particularly Loveladies and Harvey Cedars.
"There are certainly more fancy restaurants," she said. "And I do see a bit more dressing up than I used to. That has to be a New York influence."
For their part, Philadelphians and South Jerseyans are trying to hold on to what they believe is rightly theirs.
"There are still cheese steaks and miniature golf here," she said. "We convert those people, and they end up liking those things, too."
