HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Inflation Is Rising, but Don't Lose Sleep

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton; This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT has been so long since most New Yorkers have had to worry about inflation that the whole idea seems kind of retro, even quaint. After all, the last time inflation was a really big deal, Americans were eating quiche in fern bars, watching "Dallas" on network television, and being driven demented by "The Pina Colada Song."
 Not only is inflation no longer in the double digits, as it was in the late 1970's, it hasn't topped 4 percent in more than a decade. And in the last 12 months, the consumer price index has edged up just 1.5 percent. 
 So why are some economists so focused on inflation right now? There are a couple of reasons. Most of them have to do with events occurring far away, but at least one is a strictly local concern.
First of all, Alan Greenspan always worries about inflation, and so would you if you were the chairman of the Federal Reserve. Inflation was the economic scourge of the 1970's (it zoomed from about 6 percent in 1970 to more than 14 percent in early 1980).
The Fed finally managed to get inflation under control by raising interest rates, but not without provoking two recessions. 
Right now, the United States economy appears (most of the time) to be emerging from a recession, though you wouldn't know it in New York City. Increasing economic activity can bring price pressures and inflation. 
If national inflation continues to rise as fast as it did in the first three months of 2002, the consumer price index will increase by 3 percent this year, according to the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, which adjusts the data for seasonal factors. That may not sound like much, but it is almost twice the 1.6 percent increase in all of 2001.
Nationally, the biggest problem today is the same one that plagued the 1970's: high energy prices. (Of course, you're too young to remember gas lines, but you've seen pictures, right?) 
After falling sharply last year, oil prices shot up in March and have remained high; if petroleum costs keep rising at the same speed, they will be up 50 percent by the end of the year.
Of course, energy prices are volatile, and despite the recent run-up, they are still down more than 10 percent compared to this time last year. But with the continuing crisis in the Middle East, economists are not alone in worrying that there could be a significant spike in oil prices, which could trip up the national economic rebound.
The good news, for those who live in and around New York City, is that this area tends to fare relatively well in an energy crisis because of the extensive public transportation system, said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Indeed, during the late 1970's, the inflation rate for this area -- New York City and its suburbs, Long Island and northern New Jersey -- was about 2 percentage points lower than the national average.
But right now, the local inflation rate is actually a percentage point higher than the national average, noted Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist of The New York Stat, a newsletter about the regional economy. In what she calls "a disturbing trend," the local consumer price index has suddenly started climbing faster than the national index, after two years of lower increases. 
So while the national rate was 1.5 percent in the 12 months ending in March, the local rate was 2.5 percent.
The culprit appears to be housing costs, especially for people who own their own homes. It's hard to know how much to make of this, because federal inflation watchers have an odd way of measuring the costs of home ownership: they take a survey and ask people how much they could get if they rented out their homes.
In real life, in New York City, unregulated rents have been falling, not rising. And while housing prices here are astronomical, they have not been rising as fast as in, say, Modesto, Calif., according to a recent government study.
If economists are concerned about the sudden uptick in local inflation, it's mostly because they fear it will discourage people and businesses from moving here. But for locals who already own their own places, it may actually be reassuring to think that housing values are still rising, despite everything.
"We really don't want to get as far out of line with the rest of the country as we did in the 1980's," said Rae Rosen, a senior economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "But all things being equal, it's nice if you live here."

Graph shows the inflation rates for the NYC area compared to the U.S. as a whole. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
In Long Run, Residential Real Estate May Beat Stocks

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FOR all our diversity, most American investors share a common financial religion. We believe in stocks for the long run. We've taken to heart historical data showing that, over a great many years, stocks outperform other investments and beat inflation by several percentage points.
 But in investing, heresy can also pay, and I think that residential real estate will pay best in the next decade or two. Sure, home values have risen considerably, but they've done so for reasons that will continue to power prices upward for years. Eventually, home prices may fall, but America is unlikely to produce enough housing to meet all the demand. Housing continues to be tax-advantaged, and unlike stocks it can be safely leveraged with the cheapest possible capital, thanks to low mortgage rates. Housing markets, moreover, are much less efficient than the stock market, so buyers can probably get good deals if they try. 
 Perhaps the biggest factor that will drive housing prices upward is immigration. The influx of immigrants is not likely to be stopped anytime soon because there are too many reasons for it to continue, including low native birth rates, the aging of the population and the lobbying of businesses hungry for cheap and technically trained labor. In the decades ahead, immigrants will account for most of the population growth and they will drive up demand for housing. Albert Saiz, an immigrant from Spain who just received a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard, has examined the effects of immigrants on rental housing in the United States. His unpublished study found that for each 1 percent of a city's population that consists of newly arrived immigrants, rents can be expected to rise 1.5 percent.
Another factor will be the anti-sprawl backlash that limits residential development. Developers are running into increasing resistance in communities around the country, often in the form of zoning laws requiring large lot sizes, which reduce the number of new homes it is possible to build. That keeps existing homes expensive.
There is every sign that our love of second homes will persist and even deepen. Second-home sales have soared in recent years, with an estimated 415,000 homes sold in 2000, up from 296,000 in 1995. Lenders have dropped the more onerous requirements they once imposed on buyers in this category. People with expensive first homes have the equity to buy a second home, and for many Americans, retirement beckons. But many of the places they will want to retire to are either fully developed or increasingly subject to building restrictions (that is why they're still so nice, after all). In desirable coastal communities like Cape Cod, higher prices are the only possible outcome. Experience so far in Florida and Colorado, two popular states for affluent retirees, bears out this prediction. I would expect a similar phenomenon in college communities like Charlottesville, Va., which are attractive to affluent retirees.
Dennis R. Capozza, a finance professor at the University of Michigan Business School in Ann Arbor, said the relationship of rents to prices in a community can tell you a lot about whether to anticipate rising home prices. He says a low rent-to-price ratio implies appreciation ahead, whereas a high ratio of rents to prices would mean a better income investment. Since rising land values account for most or all of the capital gain on a residential property, single-family houses appreciate most. Condos appreciate less but offer the best income payout.
This sort of thing matters because taxes are a big reason for investing in residential real estate. For starters, the government lets you deduct from your income the interest on up to $1 million in mortgage debt every year on two homes for your own use. Buy an income property and everything associated with it is deductible, including an annual depreciation charge. 
There are downsides. Being a landlord is a pain, and since land is the main thing that appreciates, you might consider buying vacant lots if you don't mind forgoing the income and tying up your capital. Nor is real estate all that liquid, although technology will eventually help streamline the medieval paperwork associated with buying and selling. If it all seems like too much trouble, you can always buy real estate on Wall Street. People do it every day by buying stock in a real estate investment trust.

HEADLINE: A Doctor's Last Resort 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Patients, Not Numbers," by Marc Siegel (Op-Ed, May 1): 
 It's insulting to suggest that physicians who restrict Medicare patients are betraying the ideals of their profession. 
Many do so as a last resort and after much agonizing so they can keep their medical practices economically viable. 
 Medicare reimbursement could ultimately be cut by almost 20 percent over four years. It is naive to believe that physicians can endure such cuts and keep up with rising costs for employee wages and benefits, office overhead, medical equipment and liability premiums.
It is time to stop faulting the physicians and instead join the American Medical Association in urging Congress and the Bush administration to stop the excessive Medicare payment cuts before patient access to care deteriorates further.

J. EDWARD HILL, M.D.
Chicago, May 3, 2002

The writer is chairman-elect of the American Medical Association.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH; 
Gary L. Bergstrom and Brian Wolahan

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
EMERGING markets might have been more accurately called "submerging markets" over the last eight years or so, say Gary L. Bergstrom and Brian Wolahan, the managers of the $41 million UAM Acadian Emerging Markets Portfolio.
 In the United States, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained an average 11 percent annually from 1994 to 2001, while the Morgan Stanley Capital International Emerging Markets Free index fell an average 6.8 percent each year, Mr. Bergstrom said. 
 But they are compelling investments today, the managers said. 
First, emerging markets are cheap by just about any measure, Mr. Bergstrom said. According to the managers' calculations, as of April 30, the S.& P. 500 companies traded for 20.7 times estimated 2002 earnings compared with 14.1 times for companies in the emerging markets index. The price-to-book multiple for United States companies was 3.3 compared with 1.6 for emerging markets companies, they said.
Furthermore, emerging markets tend to rise faster than developed markets during periods of economic growth, Mr. Wolahan said, adding, "We do think that in the next year or two, there will be a pickup in global economic growth."
The fund returned 6.1 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 2.1 percent for diversified emerging markets funds, according to Morningstar Inc. It returned 27 percent in the 12 months through Thursday versus 8.7 percent for its group, Morningstar said.
Mr. Bergstrom, 61, and Mr. Wolahan, 43, work for Acadian Asset Management, the fund's adviser. Acadian, an affiliate of Old Mutual, a financial services group in Britain, also manages about $2.5 billion, mostly for institutions. The fund's $100,000 minimum investment is reduced to $2,500 for shares purchased through the Charles Schwab, Fidelity and TD Waterhouse mutual fund marketplaces.
Investing in emerging markets is inherently risky: macroeconomic and accounting data may be misleading, political and banking systems are not always stable, and exchange rates may fluctuate. As a result, the managers said, the fund should not be used as a core investment but to diversify a portfolio.
To pick 150 or so stocks, the managers evaluate more than 5,000 stocks in 30 markets each day. They rank stocks based on projected stock price appreciation in the next one to three months in United States dollar terms.
The country allocation is based on such factors as interest rates, stock market volatility and aggregate earnings forecasts. Their biggest bet is China, which represents about 10 percent of the fund's assets. Mr. Wolahan said that Chinese companies were priced cheaply, about 13 times estimated 2002 earnings.
The managers are also bullish on Russia, which is moving toward a market economy. The fund has a 9 percent stake in Russia compared with 5 percent for the diversified emerging markets funds. "Russia had a difficult time during the 90's," Mr. Wolahan said, "but they're starting to reap the benefits in the form of lower interest rates and higher G.D.P. growth."
The Brazilian market is also well priced, the managers say. "Brazil was popular in the early- to mid-90's, when they stabilized inflation," Mr. Bergstrom said, "but since then, many people are disappointed at the rate of progress." He said Brazil's drive to privatize state-owned oil and telephone companies, among others, was a strong indicator of a free-market approach.
"IN March, the managers bought shares of China Mobile for 22.95 Hong Kong dollars, or $2.94. On Friday, they closed at 26.55 Hong Kong dollars, or $3.40. The company, a leader in the Chinese mobile telecommunications market, increased its subscriber base 65 percent in the four years ending 2001, Mr. Wolahan said. Shares trade for 15 times 2002 earnings compared with 38 times earnings for ATT Wireless, he said, "so you get a good growth company at a pretty reasonable price."
In February they bought shares in Yukos, a large Russian oil company, as American depository receipts for $98. They closed Friday at $154. The company's annual oil production is expected to grow 24 percent in 2002, Mr. Bergstrom said, among the strongest forecasts for global oil companies.
Last May, they bought shares in Banco do Brasil, a Brazilian financial services company. The bank has Brazil's largest deposit base. They paid 8.51 reals for shares or $3.65. Shares closed at 13.25 reals on Friday, or $5.55.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Tariffs Won, Steel Sings New Tune

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

 BODY:
LISTENERS to the Webcasts and conference calls held by steel companies in recent weeks may be excused for wondering whether this is the same industry that a few months ago was warning that its very survival was at risk.
 Richard M. Wardrop Jr., chairman and chief executive of AK Steel, based in Middletown, Ohio, told people tuned in to his company's presentation, "We may be moving closer to being in the driver's seat than at any time since 1995." John Mayberry, chief executive of Dofasco Inc., a Canadian producer that does business in the United States, observed that "market conditions have improved much more quickly than we had anticipated." 
The main event between the dire warnings of a few months ago and the first-quarter conference calls of recent weeks has been the Bush administration's decision to impose tariffs of 8 to 30 percent on most steel imports. Though those tariffs did not go as far as some steelmakers would have liked, they have lifted the mood of industry executives and their shareholders. 
Steel prices have climbed steeply. According to surveys of steel buyers by Purchasing magazine, the average spot, or market, price of hot-rolled steel sheet, the type used for motor vehicle bodies and domestic appliances, has climbed from $215 a ton in November to $290 in April. Prices for May are expected to top $300 a ton, and some producers have announced additional increases for the summer. Prices of other types of steel are also moving up.
Investors appear to be shrugging off some unpleasant facts: more than two dozen steel companies are in some form of forced restructuring, others are still posting losses, and demand remains soft.
Steel stocks have performed better than many other sectors in recent months. The Dow Jones American steel index has climbed more than 40 percent since September. Among individual stocks, the Nucor Corporation, based in Charlotte, N.C., almost doubled in this period, reaching a peak of $66.35 in late March. The stock closed at $59.12 on Friday.
The investment climate is sufficiently encouraging that the United States Steel Corporation, based in Pittsburgh, one of the biggest producers, said last week that it planned a public offering of eight million common shares. The issue is to be priced in mid-May. The stock closed on Friday at $18.34. At the current price, the issue would raise close to $150 million, some of which may be used for acquisitions, the company said. 
"Everybody is looking up from the bottom of the hole," said Warren Isabelle, chief investment officer at Ironwood Capital Management in Boston. "Those who can climb the best have got some good things in store." Ironwood is a sizable holder of AK Steel stock, and Mr. Isabelle said he was considering buying more shares in that company and in United States Steel.
Daniel Roling, metals analyst at Merrill Lynch, has also strongly recommended AK Steel, based on rising prices and higher sales, especially to the automotive industry, which produces more than half of AK Steel's revenues.
The good news for steel producers and investors has come mostly from the supply side. Prices were starting to rise several months before President Bush approved the import tariffs in early March.
The spate of bankruptcies and reorganizations over the last year has curtailed capacity. According to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group, production of raw steel in 2001 was 11.5 percent lower than the previous year. One of the biggest casualties, the LTV Corporation, was a big producer of sheet steel. LTV, which shut down its mills in December and was bought by an investor group, accounted for 8 percent of North American output.
The tariffs, which Mr. Isabelle described as "a little bit of gravy," have had the effect of choking off low-priced foreign supplies, making it easier for domestic producers to raise prices.
According to the institute, steel imports fell to 2,034,000 tons in March, down 39.4 percent from February. Meanwhile, the domestic industry's capacity utilization has risen from 77.8 percent in early January to 87.5 percent in the week ended April 27. In addition, steel distributors' inventories are low.
If spot prices stay at current levels, steelmakers are sure to start pressing for better terms in long-term contracts with their customers. Referring to contract negotiations for 2003, Mr. Wardrop at AK Steel told analysts that talk in the industry was of a 6 to 8 percent increase in contract prices.
Christopher Olin, analyst at Midwest Research in Cleveland, forecast that contract prices for the coming year will rise 5 percent. "We're pretty bullish on steel," Mr. Olin said.
Rising prices have helped not only the steel industry in the United States, but also producers in Canada and Mexico, which are exempt from the new duties and rely heavily on trade and investments in the United States. For instance, Ipsco, based in Regina, Saskatchewan, produces about two-thirds of its steel at plants in Iowa and Alabama. Other Canadian producers are big suppliers to the auto industry. "The North American steel industry is very much integrated," said Anna Sorbo, an analyst at CIBC World Markets in Toronto.
The Canadian and Mexican authorities are also taking steps to protect their producers from offshore competition, creating what Randolph Cousins, an analyst at BMO Nesbitt Burns in Toronto, calls "fortress North America."
Several countries have complained to the World Trade Organization about the American tariffs. The European Union is threatening to retaliate by imposing additional duties on imports from the United States worth about $300 million a year.
The brighter mood in the industry does not mean its troubles are over. The problem of legacy costs -- health care and other benefits for retirees, which are estimated at more than $10 billion -- continues to hamper industry restructuring. Mr. Wardrop complained that delays in completing bankruptcy proceedings were holding up his company's plans to bolster profitability by acquiring more capacity to produce coated steel, which has a protective layer.
While Canadian and Mexican companies are typically burdened by lower legacy costs than American producers, analysts say that American companies are restructuring or finding other ways to lighten their legacy cost burdens. 
PLANT closures and tariffs have reined in supply and tighter cost controls have brought down operating costs, but few would dare pronounce the industry firmly on the road to recovery until there is a sustained increase in demand. That has yet to happen.
James Alfano, chief executive of Stelco Inc., the biggest Canadian producer, said, "We expect to see steel demand increase as the North American economy strengthens." 
Executives at United States Steel told analysts last week that second-quarter orders for sheet steel were strong, with stable demand from the automotive and appliance sectors. General Motors has said that it plans to raise new car and truck production by 4 percent in the second quarter, compared with a year ago.
But, according to United States Steel, demand for steel plate, widely used in construction and shipbuilding, remained flat. In addition, the market for specialty steel pipes, used for oil and gas drilling and transportation, was soft, bridge-building was threatened by cuts in government spending and the rail-car market was about half its normal level.
Mr. Cousins at BMO Nesbitt Burns said he was "steering away" from steel-sheet producers, like Nucor, which depend heavily on the automotive and housing sectors. Sheet made up 46 percent of Nucor's first-quarter output. "It can't get any better" for these companies, Mr. Cousins said. "Those are stocks that have had huge runs."

HEADLINE: Business; 
A Handicapper's Guide to the Trial of Andersen

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
NO defendant will be visible in the courtroom. The white-collar prosecution will be presented to the down-home Texas jury by a couple of East Coast organized-crime busters. The chief witness will admit to committing a crime, while the defense will say he is an innocent man who's lying. At stake is the survival of the once-powerful accounting firm, Arthur Andersen.
 The criminal trial of Andersen on a single charge of obstruction of justice in the Enron case opens in a Houston courtroom tomorrow with jury selection. The case is expected to last just weeks -- a blink of an eye by the standard of white-collar criminal trials. While some 40 members of the media are expected in the courtroom, there is unlikely to be live Court TV commentary or spectators camping out overnight to get seats. But it promises to be one of the more unusual and important confrontations in years. 
The issues are simple: Were thousands of documents related to Enron's finances shredded last fall for the corrupt intent of impeding an official inquiry? If so, should Andersen be held accountable for the actions of employees who committed a crime? 
On paper, at least, the answers to those questions appear to be a slam-dunk for the prosecution. The government has a guilty plea in its back pocket from David B. Duncan, the Andersen partner who orchestrated the destruction, and he has told federal investigators that the shredding was the outgrowth of months of discussions among members of the firm. 
Criminal trials are not won on paper, but in the jury room. That wild card offers opportunities for both sides in a trial that is about little more than shredded paper.
Still, for Andersen, the outcome could mean life or death. And for the government, the credibility of the investigation into potential fraud at Enron could be hugely damaged by a defeat on such a simple case. With victory for both sides so shallow and defeat such a calamity, legal experts still marvel that this case is even going to trial.
"The crystal clear issue here is that both sides have overplayed their hands," said James Moriarty, a Houston lawyer who has brought numerous white-collar civil cases. "Now both sides are backed into a position that neither one should want to be in."
In many ways, the Andersen trial will be like the final game of a tough World Series, with strategies playing out in a manner that is obvious only to aficionados of the game and with the winner taking all. So, like any good sports fan, those wanting to handicap this trial need a program to study. Understanding the players and their strategies means understanding where this case is likely to end.

The Prosecutors
The government lawyers are Samuel W. Buell and Andrew Weissmann, assistant United States attorneys from the East Coast who were assigned this year by the Justice Department to the Enron task force. Both are reputed to be hard-bitten prosecutors willing to push aggressively on tough cases.
Both are best known for their prosecutions of organized crime figures. Two years ago, for example, Mr. Buell helped bring an indictment against James J. Bulger, a powerful gangster known as Whitey from the Irish enclave in South Boston. Mr. Bulger was a long-time informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but maintained a strong hand in criminal activities, including accusations of killing more than a dozen people. The case was a scandal in Boston, and Mr. Buell was at the forefront of setting things right. But Mr. Bulger became a fugitive before he could be put on trial.
Mr. Weissmann, formerly the head of the criminal division for the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn, also specialized in organized crime prosecutions. He worked with Salvatore Gravano -- the gangland hitman-turned-informant better known as Sammy the Bull -- in taking on prominent organized crime figures in New York City. 
The prosecutors' backgrounds have served as something of an undercurrent in the case. Repeatedly, Andersen partners have grumbled that the prosecutors seemed intent on treating the firm like a mob enterprise, and were unable to recognize that it was much more than a potential crime incubator. At trial, some legal experts said, the prosecutors will deftly have to attack the crime but not alienate the jury by treating Andersen like a criminal organization.

The Defense
Andersen's team is led by Rusty Hardin, a former prosecutor who served as chief trial counsel in the Whitewater investigation during the Clinton administration. Mr. Hardin is perhaps best known for his celebrity cases, including his star turn going up against Anna Nicole Smith, the former Playboy model, in a battle over the estate of her late husband, J. Howard Marshall II. Mr. Hardin represented a son of Mr. Marshall, and won the case.
Mr. Hardin, a fixture in Houston legal circles, is widely viewed as the lawyer who might just pull off a miracle in the Andersen case. His rapport with juries is legendary, as is his skill at cross-examination, and both are expected to play critical roles. "Rusty Hardin is a genius," said Mr. Moriarty. "If there is anybody in the world who can grab victory out of jaws of defeat, it's him."

The Judge
Throughout Houston, Judge Melinda F. Harmon of the United States District Court has the reputation as a tough, law-and-order judge who is decidedly fair. She has served on the bench for nearly 13 years.
"The judge is going to be a real factor in this case, because she is the kind of judge who makes her presence felt," said Dick DeGuerin, a criminal defense lawyer in Houston. "She is a hands-on, take-charge kind of judge who will take over a slow cross-examination or slow direct exam."
That may serve Mr. Hardin to some degree because he already has a working familiarity with her. "Rusty Hardin is of a temperament to handle that better than some out-of-town lawyers who don't know her," Mr. DeGuerin said.

The Star Witness
Until the debacle at Enron, Mr. Duncan was an Andersen lifer, having joined the firm out of Texas A & M in 1981, where he had earned a degree in accounting. From then on, he was a man on the move, hustling up the ranks until he became the lead partner serving Enron, one of Andersen's biggest and most prestigious clients.
Last October, Mr. Duncan made the decision that transformed him from a numbers cruncher to a national symbol of Enron's collapse. One day after learning that the Securities and Exchange Commission was about to seek Enron's auditing records as part of a preliminary inquiry into its financial problems, Mr. Duncan orchestrated a massive campaign to destroy records. For months, he maintained that he only did so in response to an Oct. 12 e-mail message from a company lawyer telling members of the Enron team to insure that they were in compliance with Andersen's policies on document retention and destruction.
Then, last month, Mr. Duncan pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, agreeing to become the government's chief witness in the Andersen case. In his statement to the court then, he said the documents were destroyed "so that they would be unavailable to the S.E.C. and others."
With that admission, Mr. Duncan provided prosecutors with their most important evidence of intent to impede an investigation -- a critical element of proof necessary for a conviction. Now, his statements will serve as the primary evidence of criminal intent within Andersen.

The Strategies
One of the most important moments in the Andersen case, legal experts said, would likely occur on the first day -- and could pass by almost unnoticed. For the selection of a jury, Judge Harmon has often allowed the lawyers to conduct individual questioning of prospective members, a process known as voir dire. Usually in federal trials on the East Coast, lawyers said, such interviews are handled by the judge, who questions large pools of possible jurors.
As a result, legal experts said, if Judge Harmon holds to form and allows for individual voir dire by the lawyers in this case, Mr. Hardin may start with a leg up.
"Individual voir dire will be a huge advantage to Rusty," said David H. Berg, a prominent Houston trial lawyer. "It is a fading art and there aren't many who can do it well. But Rusty is one who can."
The voir dire not only allows lawyers to detect bias, but also gives them a free opportunity to begin stressing the themes of their cases during questioning, essentially priming the witnesses for the arguments they are about to hear at trial.
"There are subtle ways to condition jurors in voir dire, there are subtle ways to persuade jurors to vote your way," Mr. Berg said. But unlike most white-collar trials, where the crime can seem distant and vague, the inextricable links between this case and the Enron investigation will likely serve as a plus for the government. 
"The underlying economic disaster here has harmed thousands of Houstonians and will be one of the most memorable financial disasters in this city's history," Mr. Moriarty said. "The problem of jury selection is to find 12 people who will admit or claim that they haven't made up their minds."
After opening statements, the government will begin presenting its case. Several legal experts said that they expected the case to move quickly, with Mr. Duncan being brought to the stand as soon as possible so that the jurors can see a live witness testifying that a crime did indeed occur.
During that testimony, one important responsibility for the prosecutors is to address Mr. Duncan's apparent contradictions over time, with his shift from an insistence that he had done nothing wrong to an admission that he committed a crime.
The most important element of Mr. Duncan's direct examination will be how well the government succeeds in portraying his actions as part of a concerted effort within Andersen. To demonstrate that, there will be much discussion of the conversations among Andersen partners that began as far back as August about possible problems at Enron, and the likelihood of a federal inquiry. They will also rely on the Oct. 12 e-mail message from the Andersen lawyer reminding its Enron team about the firm's policies on document retention.
The high point of the trial, when the case could either be won or lost, will be during Mr. Hardin's cross-examination of Mr. Duncan, legal experts said. Mr. Hardin will try to persuade the jury that Mr. Duncan pleaded guilty not because he thought he had committed a crime, but because he feared a lengthy prison sentence if he went to trial. 
"The most telling thing, the thing that a jury can understand the best, is why Duncan is doing what he is doing, which is to save his own rear end," Mr. DeGuerin said.
Mr. Hardin will also try to demonstrate during his cross-examination that Mr. Duncan intentionally had tried to mislead his partners about the actions he was taking, evidence that could help Andersen in making its case that he was a rogue employee who acted outside of the firm's rules. 
During the defense's presentation, Mr. Hardin will try to humanize the firm, to portray it not as some monolithic, conniving organization, but as a collection of people trying to do the right thing. 
One enormous challenge for Mr. Hardin, however, is how to portray Andersen as a reputable organization without opening the door to rebuttal evidence from the government. If Mr. Hardin goes too far, by eliciting general testimony about the firm's good character, under what is known as Rule 404(b), prosecutors would then be able to introduce evidence of other "bad acts" by the firm. Those would include its role in the accounting fraud at Waste Management, which resulted in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and in other high-profile accounting embarrassments, including those at the Baptist Foundation of Arizona and at Sunbeam. The danger of such information being trotted out to the jury is particularly high in Judge Harmon's court, legal experts said, because she tends to allow the admission of a lot of 404(b) evidence if the defense opens the door.
The challenges to both sides are so large that, even as lawyers handicap the outcome, many insist that a settlement may well be possible. After all, both sides have little to gain in a victory, and much to lose in defeat. But a settlement would come at the last minute, when the inevitability of trial and the last long walk to court will be putting pressure on both sides.
"That," said Mr. Berg, the Houston lawyer, "Is what they invented courthouse steps for."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Despite Appearances, Economy Is Still Shaky

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
HOW comes the hard part.
 Put aside the recession, and the marvelous surge in the first quarter. That certainly did wonders for appearances. But in fact the American economy is like a brightly painted pier without enough piles to support it. Step too hard in the wrong place and the pier sags into the water. The hard part is putting enough piles in place before reality overwhelms appearance. 
 Just two piles sustained appearances in the first quarter, making the economy seem sturdy. They were stepped-up government spending, for defense at the federal level and public works at the state and local levels, and stepped-up business spending to maintain stockpiles of merchandise after they were depleted during the recession. Take away these supports and the economic growth rate, instead of being a robust 5.8 percent at an annual rate, as announced, would have been a meager 1.3 percent. 
"When you see a number like 5.8 percent, 'Well,' you say, 'the recession is over,' but that is not what the Commerce Department told us in the latest G.D.P. report," said Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
The G.D.P., or gross domestic product, is the total value of all the goods and services produced each year in the United States. The Commerce Department calculates the G.D.P. quarterly and these calculations have become the most popular measure of the economy's ups and downs. A 3 percent annual growth rate is generally considered the minimum necessary to give people the feel of prosperity. Less than 3 percent is insufficient to generate enough jobs to keep down the unemployment rate or enough tax revenue to maintain public spending at the state and local levels -- among other ills.
Less than 3 percent appears to lie ahead for most, if not all, of this year. Government spending and inventory maintenance, for example, are unlikely to be as supportive as they were in the recent past. 
The G.D.P. report for the first quarter -- once the piles were counted -- was the first clear signal that the quick recovery that everyone yearns for, and that many forecasters still promise, is unlikely. In case anyone missed the signal, the employment report on Friday amplified it. With job creation almost nonexistent, the unemployment rate jumped to 6 percent in April from 5.7 percent in March. It goes almost without saying that the Federal Reserve's policy makers, when they meet on Tuesday to discuss interest rates, will not raise them. Just a couple of months ago, many forecasters had expected rates to be rising by now, in anticipation of a potentially inflationary growth rate.
"We are compiling a picture of an economy that is going to struggle," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com. 
Economic growth is a tricky concept. Even without growth, the dynamic American economy churns out more than $10 trillion a year in goods and services. That number has to rise continuously, however, by at least $300 billion a year to generate enough incomes and jobs. Each additional $100 billion increase adds a percentage point to the G.D.P.'s growth rate. 
In these metrics, inventory replenishment contributed a very hefty 3.1 percentage points to the first quarter's 5.8 percent growth rate. That sort of replenishment is not likely to be topped this quarter, with its sudden signals of weak growth. Why replenish only to be stuck with unsold goods? 
Government spending shows similar stress, after contributing 1.4 percentage points to first-quarter growth, half of it at the federal level and half at the state and local levels. Federal spending went up because of rising outlays for defense. That could happen again. But many states and cities have begun to slash spending in response to less-than-expected tax revenue.
THERE are the usual standbys, of course. Residential construction added 0.7 percentage point. House building, already at a record level, rose more. Can it go even higher in the second quarter, making another contribution to growth? Most experts are doubtful. Consumer spending is the other heavy hitter. But consumer spending at home cannot be separated in the G.D.P. from net exports, which are what we sell to foreign consumers minus the greater amount we import. Together, consumer spending, globally defined, contributed only 1.3 percentage points in the first quarter, and is in danger of falling in the second.
That leaves hope. The expectation of Kathleen Cooper, the Commerce Department's undersecretary for economic affairs, is that profits will revive, encouraging business to step up investment in machinery and software, lifting growth. Maybe. There is already stirring in this quarter. But not enough to qualify as piles supporting the glossily painted, but shaky pier.

HEADLINE: Energy Decisions, State by State 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The energy plan being debated in Washington (editorial, April 28) fails to provide for our energy and environmental needs. Its billion-dollar subsidies to the fossil fuel and nuclear industries will result in damaging the environment and endangering millions, as with the Indian Point nuclear plant (letters, April 29). 
 With national policy so clearly heading down the wrong tracks, the most important energy decisions now fall to state decision makers, who should move to increase renewable energy. California especially has a prime opportunity to do just that. 
California decision makers should commit to doubling our use of clean, renewable energy to 20 percent of power generation by 2010. This would help the state's economy by adding thousands of new jobs. More important, it would provide power without sacrificing our health or our environment.

ELI RICHLIN
Los Angeles, April 30, 2002

The writer is energy associate, California Public Interest Research Group.

HEADLINE: Public Colleges, Broken Promises 

 BODY:
The United States set out nearly 30 years ago to ensure that Americans who qualified academically would not be turned away from college for financial reasons. The bedrock of the program was a dual system: state legislatures subsidized public universities to keep tuition low, while the poorest students could get federal Pell Grants that largely covered the remaining costs. Within a few years of setting that goal, the attempt to secure the broadest possible access to college seemed secure. Since then, spiraling tuition and declining support for poor and working-class students have combined to roll back one of the more farsighted policies of the 20th century. 
 The problem was laid out yet again last week in two reports, one entitled "Losing Ground," from the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, and a second, from Congress, called "Slamming Shut the Doors to College." A national policy once based primarily on need-based grants is now dominated by loan programs that often require Americans to assume unmanageable debts. Once seen as a benefit to society as a whole, a college education is now viewed as a boon to an individual, who should be forced to pay for it. 
 The data in the new reports shows that public colleges, which educate more than three-quarters of America's students, are becoming unaffordable for many American families, that federal and state financial aid to students has failed to keep pace with tuition increases and that low-income families in particular are borrowing larger amounts than ever to pay for college. Both Republicans and Democrats participated in the destructive process of shifting aid that was once dispensed on the basis of need toward more politically powerful middle- and upper-income families.
The dearth of student aid for lower-income families is discouraging the neediest from applying to college at all and driving them toward low-paying jobs that keep them at the very margins of society. These are ominous developments at a time when a college diploma has become the ticket for admission into the new economy and a basic requirement for a middle-class life. The most alarming figures show that the college attendance gap between high-income and low-income Americans has widened and that about a quarter of high-achieving low-income students fail to go to college at all.
"Losing Ground" appears just as public universities have responded to recession-driven budget cuts with steep tuition increases. Public colleges must absorb a reasonable share of pain, but the states are killing their own futures by pricing the poorest students out of college and into dead-end jobs. The states also need to re-examine their approaches to university building, which, in the name of economic development, situates costly campuses in remote areas where they are not needed.
Failing to finance the federal Pell Grant program at a realistic level has a truly corrosive effect. In 1986, Pell Grants covered 98 percent of the tuition at a public four-year college. Today, that figure is 57 percent. The erosion of aid has been aggravated by the fact that federal and state governments are moving away from need-based aid to politically popular tax credits and other programs that shift a huge share of public education dollars toward the more affluent. Unless the country renews its commitment to helping poor and working-class students get to and through college, upward mobility for tens of millions of Americans will effectively cease.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Remodeling? Consider the Resale Value.

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
With the economy improving and temperatures warming, more Americans may be considering home improvements. While the costs for projects vary, so does the payoff after a home is sold. 
 Remodeled kitchens and bathrooms netted the highest return when houses were sold. But converting a room into a home office was estimated to return only 55 percent of its costs, on average, according to Remodeling magazine. Returns for that project can be greater in certain parts of the country, like Atlanta, where commutes can be long, or in cities like San Francisco, where there are many jobs in high-technology fields. Real estate agents ranked the return on home offices at more than 100 percent in those cities, according to the magazine.
 KATHLEEN O'BRIEN

HEADLINE: Different Lives, One Goal: Finding the Key to College 

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
The race begins at different times and in different ways. 
 Jed Resnick roars from the gate like a performance car, motor humming, pit crew of parents and guidance counselor all focused on a single shining goal: Yale. 
 Reuben Quansah ambles warily but purposefully, learning the terrain as he goes. He discovers that an African-American teenager from a low-income family can play the college admission game as well as the children of privilege who once considered it their own. 
Gerta Xhelo, the daughter of Albanian immigrants, ignores the starter's pistol, misses cues, dawdles lazily. But at the very last minute she wakes up and rushes to the finish line. 
In most ways, Jed Resnick, son of a doctor and a social worker who attends the exclusive Collegiate School in Manhattan; Reuben Quansah, whose mother scrimped to send him to Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx; and Gerta Xhelo, whose parents' long journey in search of a better life has taken her to Grover Cleveland High School in Queens, inhabit separate universes. 
Their dissimilar expectations, resources and sophistication define how they approach America's coming-of-age obsession: applying to college. This game confers distinct advantages and disadvantages on each of these three young people. In the end, there are enough opportunities and obstacles to go around. 
The New York Times followed Jed, Reuben and Gerta through the college admission process from spring of junior year until spring of senior year, from the evolution of their list of schools to the anxiety of SAT's, from the scramble to churn out applications to the agonizing wait for acceptance letters and financial aid packages. 
Once this rite of passage, which ended on May 1, the deadline for students to decide which college to attend, was like a secret handshake, with insider information the preserve of families with old money and long pedigrees. Only after World War II did a college education become an upper-middle-class expectation. A generation later, it had become an obsession for well-to-do baby boomers and their children, particularly in the Northeast. 
Now the game is open to all comers, thanks to the expansion of minority recruiting, democratic access to information on the Internet and scholarships and remedial programs that make higher education more widely available than ever before. A result is a growing number of students vying for a static number of slots at the nation's 3,500 colleges and universities, perhaps 50 the focus of feverish interest. 
Harvard had 19,605 applications this year for 1,650 spots, versus 13,029 a decade ago. At Pomona College in Claremont, Calif., the most recent applicant pool was 4,229 for 390 spaces, contrasted with 2,883 in 1992. And at Washington University in St. Louis, 19,512 applicants competed for 1,280 places in the freshman class, up from 8,329 a decade ago.
This crushing competition has intensified anxiety for those at the top, who over three decades have seen the game shift from one where they competed mostly against one another to one with many new players. And it has thrown those lower on the economic ladder into an arcane contest that offers them a good deal if they figure out how to navigate the system.
One thing that transcends class lines is the phenomenon of packaging, with students shrewdly massaging their resumes and counselors, playing the role of political spin doctors, relentlessly marketing them. Everyone finds the process off-putting and everyone knows it is essential. 
Beyond the packaging, there are other shared experiences. All three students have averages close to 90 and are considered accomplished but not superstars. All have veteran counselors and caring, involved parents anxious about the outcome. All have weathered family crises this year, from divorce to unemployment. 
All have obsessed over test scores, worried whether their extracurricular activities were sufficient, pulled too many all-nighters. All have expressed what Gerta did in an e-mail message in November:
"The college office is full of students now, crazy seniors like myself that are SOOOO scared and SOOOO worried they'll miss deadlines that they ask the same question two thousand times. The applications are SOOOO long and there's SOOOO much I have to write. I think I am going to die soon. I never thought it would be this hard."

Jed Resnick
Usual Advantages May Not Work
When Jed and his parents sat down with his guidance counselor, Bruce Breimer, at 7:15 on a blustery May morning last year, they already knew the rules of the admissions game. 
His parents knew which set of schools were the be-all and end-all in their social circle. They knew an early-decision application raised the odds of acceptance for upper-middle-class achievers who were not minority students, second-generation Ivy Leaguers, recruited athletes or favorites of trustees. 
They knew they could pay tuition for Jed and his twin brother, Micah, who had all the advantages of an elementary and secondary education at Collegiate. They knew that Mr. Breimer was the best in the business, part strategist and part family therapist. They knew they would survive because they had twice before, sending two older boys to Williams College, Josh in 1992 and Seth in 1995. 
They knew that Jed, a gifted singer and actor and a Greek scholar, had already set his heart on Yale, for reasons both rational and emotional. And they also knew, intellectually but not viscerally, that Jed would have a tough time getting accepted. Or at least they should have, because Mr. Breimer had told them so.
"You're a white upper-middle-class generalist; I don't think you'll get in," the counselor said repeatedly. In the lingo of the trade, Jed had no hook, unless they could parlay his theatrical talent. 
Mr. Breimer, a graduate of Collegiate ('63) and Yale ('67) in simpler times, arrived at the family conference first, rumpled as always, toting paperwork in shopping bags. He lumbered past the bulletin board, with its postings for tutors and beach houses. He stopped to soothe an agitated mother, whose son, a senior, had been rejected. "Did he take the wrong classes?" she wailed. 
Jed's parents, Terri Dancik and Jack Resnick, in the midst of a bitter divorce, arrived separately, never spoke to each other and avoided eye contact. Mr. Breimer insists on one conference that includes both parents. Divorce is common, and he needs an early reading of whether the adults will "bond" or "chew the kid up." 
The conference began with the assumption that Jed would apply to the same colleges as his classmates, despite Mr. Breimer's efforts to get them all to think beyond the "right sweatshirt to wear on Park Avenue." It is a lost cause. Between 1997 and 2001, half of Collegiate's 249 graduates went to just eight schools: Harvard (23), Yale (21), Columbia (17), Williams (16), the University of Pennsylvania (13), Brown (12), Wesleyan (12) and Vassar (10). 
Jed understands, dimly, how foolish this is. "My dad went to Brooklyn College and he's a perfectly happy, successful doctor," he said. But Ivy League aspirations are part of the air he breathes. So Jed is compelled by the destinations of his friends. The Yale list rolls easily off his tongue: Andy Sandberg from Browning; Elizabeth Kelly, his Chapin co-star in a production of "Godspell"; Quin Krovatin from Collegiate. 
Jed's parents also know that Mr. Breimer takes a dim view of early decision, in which a student applies to only one college and promises to attend if accepted. Calling it a rush to judgment, he sets the bar high, requiring visits to five campuses and then an explanation why one is a compelling match. A result is a far lower percentage of early-decision applications than at comparable schools: 30 percent in 2002, for instance, versus 75 percent at Trinity.
Dr. Resnick had reservations about Jed as an early-decision candidate because of more B's than A's in sophomore year, when his son was "stressed out" by the marital separation and shuttling between his mother's apartment on Roosevelt Island and his father's on West End Avenue. 
Mr. Breimer was noncommittal about whether early decision was right for Jed. "At some schools, there's a decided advantage," he said. "Is Yale one?" Dr. Resnick asked. "Not necessarily," the counselor replied. In 2000, 5 of 5 Collegiate early applicants got in to Yale. In 2001 the school went 0-for-3. 
As for the dip in grades, Mr. Breimer did not share Dr. Resnick's concern. If Jed "closed strongly," he would be able to "plausibly posture himself anywhere." 
Jed's mother's big worry was the boy's recent SAT scores, 680 on the verbal test and 750 in math, for a total of 1,430. Mr. Breimer agreed that the verbal score was "slightly suppressed in the context of upper-middle-class New York," where children begin learning the tricks of standardized testing in the first grade. Jed would not be a credible candidate at Yale, Mr. Breimer said, unless he nudged himself up to 1,500. 
"But we're talking about two or three more right answers, period," Mr. Breimer said. "You don't have to blow the top off the test." He was hoping this concrete nugget would quiet the clamor for a private SAT tutor, ubiquitous in this set. But "Ask Jed about tutor" remained on his mother's to-do list for months to come. 
"I'm telling you, Terri, don't do it," the counselor said. Mr. Breimer turned to Jed: "If you're as good as we think you are, you'll take care of business. And scores don't place you in; they just place you out." 
Mr. Breimer had his own concern: Jed's tendency to overextend himself because of his hectic performing schedule, at four theaters beside Collegiate's. The week before, he tried to wiggle out of the junior class rafting trip on the Delaware River because of the last two rehearsals for "Pippin" on Roosevelt Island. He wound up going to one rehearsal and then joining the class, only to return exhausted and hoarse.
Talk turned to how Mr. Breimer would put the best spin on elements of Jed's resume. A semester in Normandy as an exchange student and another at an alternative school in Vermont? These "play nicely" as a demonstration of adventurous spirit. A childhood on Roosevelt Island? Proof the Resnicks had avoided Manhattan "provincialism." 
Between them, Jed and Mr. Breimer considered 20 possible schools. For each the counselor offered a capsule review.
Brown? "The most successful urban renewal in the Northeast. A good theater town." Middlebury? "Too remote." Wesleyan? "A meshuga school, but good writing and theater." Penn? "Kids that used to waltz in aren't anymore." Swarthmore? "You're too intense already." 
"He's a master," Ms. Dancik said of Mr. Breimer as the meeting ended. "That's why I can sit back and relax. Sort of."
But for Jed, relaxing was not an option. He spent his summer at the Stagedoor Manor theatrical camp in the Catskills, taking on demanding productions like Stephen Sondheim's dark "Assassins" -- a huge jump from frothy musicals that are standards for school-age actors. The role convinced Jed that he wanted two things -- great theater and a challenging liberal arts education. Throw in the designer label, and more than ever his heart was set on Yale.
Mr. Breimer thought Jed, although a long shot, was a perfect fit. So he said he dissuaded other early applicants from the 46-member senior class, clearing the field for Jed.
Now came the breathless juggling of schoolwork, campus visits and applications. During 10 days in October, Jed had exams in Advanced Placement biology and European history, trips to the University of Michigan, Northwestern and Vassar and the SAT's. 
After the make-it-or-break-it tests, Ms. Dancik found herself voicing the persistent complaint of the privileged classes: that scores mattered so much for boys like Jed, while minority applicants had slack. "You have had every privilege," she said, "and in a way it's a disadvantage."
The next day, twitchy with strain, Jed went to Brown. He was rehearsing three plays, designing his yearbook page, writing his newspaper column -- and falling behind in his studies.
Jed's interview at Yale was Oct. 18, a rushed encounter with a bored senior who was 15 minutes late. But he spent the night at Davenport residential college with a Collegiate alumnus, went to a class in Greek tragedy with a second New York City friend and took a campus tour led by a third.
"Everyone says, 'Jed, you belong here,' " he said. "They're my kind of people. I fit in." 
Jed worked on his essays on the trip from New Haven but did not meet Mr. Breimer's standards. The counselor ripped the essays to shreds, saying they focused too much on theater and not enough on academics. 
Their editing session stopped at the moment when Jed could get expedited SAT scores by phone, for a $15 fee, a luxury neither Reuben nor Gerta could consider but a necessity in Jed's crowd.
Jed dialed his cellphone, punched in a Visa card number, waited and then waited some more. Finally, slamming his fist on the table, he shouted, each time louder, "Yes, YES. YES!!!"
His math score had nudged up to 760; his verbal jumped to 740. Mr. Breimer was particularly pleased because, in the admissions competition, which pits colleges against colleges, as well as applicants against applicants, 1,500 is "exponentially better" than 1490. 
The difference matters, Mr. Breimer said, because U.S. News & World Report says it does, tallying SAT scores in bands of 100.
The magazine's numerical rankings of colleges have added stress to the process, both for students who may prefer No. 11 to No. 21, however arbitrary the distinction may be, and for college administrators with a stake in their standing. So by hitting 1,500, Jed could play his own small part in boosting Yale's status.
Now he raced the deadline for early applications. Jed's package made the last FedEx pickup on Oct. 31.
"I'm free," he said.

Reuben Quansah
'It All Depends On Money'
Reuben's official introduction to the college admissions game came last spring at the weekly junior class assembly at Cardinal Hayes High School, which is conducted by Bill Lessa, the college counselor, who briskly presents the intricacies of the process to teenagers who, for the most part, have not given it a moment's thought. 
Reuben was ahead of the pack. His older brother, Rickie, had just been accepted at Wentworth Institute of Technology in Boston and Reuben had shared the yearlong ordeal. He had already been to two college fairs, had visited two upstate campuses and was cramming for his approaching SAT's. 
Still he filed quietly with his classmates across marble floors and Oriental rugs and into the school's dim auditorium, on Grand Concourse a few blocks from Yankee Stadium. From 8:13 to 8:37, not counting the opening Hail Mary, Mr. Lessa discussed the standardized test schedule, the local college fairs, the Web sites and the guidebooks.
This is no boutique like Collegiate, where Mr. Breimer says "the clock is not an issue." Mr. Lessa, along with a 200-plus caseload, works a second job, supervising custodians at an East Bronx school. Still, Reuben knew he was welcome in the counselor's office anytime, and he went almost every day. 
Reuben began his search with less social pressure than Jed. Cardinal Hayes, like Collegiate, is for boys only, but there the similarity ends. At the Bronx school, a few each year go to the Ivy League, but many more choose Roman Catholic colleges and affordable SUNY or CUNY campuses. 
But Reuben was No. 15 in a class of 230, a star in a demanding Cisco Systems computer course. He had already been singled out for membership in the select Archbishop's Leadership Program, which teaches critical thinking, interpersonal skills and black history. At weekly meetings at a Harlem church, these motivated teenagers organize trips to college campuses, raising the money and preparing questions for admissions officers. With them, Reuben had already visited Colgate and the State University at Binghamton. 
That put him ahead of the curve at the first junior class assembly, where Mr. Lessa laid out the criteria for choosing schools. Big or small? Public or private? Urban or rural? Home or away? Going out of town raises issues for inner-city students. Boys from the Grand Concourse are rarely moved by the bright foliage at Amherst or the snowy landscape at Bates when it means giving up the D train and the corner bodega. 
Part of the presentation was geography. "A guy who wants to go to Buffalo needs to know that Buffalo is far away and it's cold there," Mr. Lessa said. "These young men do not know what it means when I say 'rural' or 'suburban.' They may have been to New Roc City and think that's a suburb." 
Reuben was on the fence about going away. He was drawn to the idea of a "real" college experience. But he worried about his mother, Maureen Dowouna-Nortey, a nurse-technician who had taken on burdensome loans when Rickie's financial aid package fell $9,000 short of the mark.
Mr. Lessa had failed to persuade Rickie to chose a state college. Ms. Dowouna-Nortey was already working double shifts at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx, struggling to pay $3,750 parochial school tuitions and send money to relatives in Africa. The boys' father had abandoned the family a dozen years before, Ms. Dowouna-Nortey said, adding that their stepfather, moving in and out of the house as the marriage foundered, did not help with household expenses.
"It all depends on money," Reuben said.
Financial aid would be the topic of the next assembly. Mr. Lessa warned them that he needed to know family income, information that "parents don't readily share with children" but that would be essential. Then he turned the microphone over to Brother Christopher Keogan, the dean of discipline, who read off the day's detention list. 
Students at Cardinal Hayes must sit up straight, keep their lockers tidy and use honorifics when addressing adults. Dreadlocks are forbidden and shirttails must be tucked in. The Rev. James Byrnes, the academic dean, said students put on "a certain persona on the street" but are "glad when they get here to leave it at the door." Heading home each day, parochial school boys on the Grand Concourse shed their ties and yank out their shirttails. 
For Reuben, there is no costume change.
With hundreds of other teenagers in puffy jackets and low-slung jeans, Reuben's blazer, tie and briefcase drew admiring stares at a college fair in October at the Westchester County Center in White Plains.
In his briefcase Reuben carried an alphabetical list of representatives he wanted to meet -- from Bucknell, Clarkson, Manhattan College, New York Institute of Technology -- and questions to ask them.
Is the curriculum heavier on computer networking or programming? Is there a campus chapter of the Society of Black Engineers? Are students involved in faculty research? Can he earn a combined bachelor's and master's degree in five years?
"This is a level of maturity one rarely sees," said Mr. Lessa, as he watched him work the cavernous room. "What you hope is that someone recognizes that.""
People already had.
There was Beryl S. Jeffers, a SUNY admissions official, who conducted an assembly at Hayes a year ago about the state's 64-campus system. Reuben solemnly introduced himself before asking a question, as he had been taught at his weekend retreats with the Archbishop's Leadership Program. "It struck me right away," Ms. Jeffers said. Such polished manners were rare.
Then came Gloria Walker, the office manager in the information technology department at Bellevue Hospital Center, where Reuben had had a summer internship. "That lady from Bellevue, she kept saying to me, 'How did you raise this kid?' " said Reuben's mother. Reuben is the youngest of her four children, but the one she calls an old soul.
At the fair, Reuben kept his distance from classmates with less serious agendas. One tried to distract him with the suggestion that they "look for girls." Reuben declined politely. But there was ice in his stare.
Working his way up the aisles, Reuben found the Bucknell table. The school was an unlikely choice, deep in rural Pennsylvania, and Reuben had only recently added it to his list because of the engineering department and the new focus on minority students. 
Bucknell is highly selective but rated a notch below the top tier of schools lusted after by upper-middle-class teenagers, as much for their status as their academic worth. But Reuben was not impressed by brand names. He wanted a school that would propel him toward a career in computer engineering and help him pay for it. 
Reuben struck up an easy conversation with Kate Peltz, Bucknell's representative. Ms. Peltz described the various engineering curriculums. She gave him a brochure intended for black and Hispanic students. Bucknell had 12 percent minority enrollment and was pushing hard to do better.
She registered Reuben's fastidious dress, behavior and preparation. Afterward, Ms. Peltz sent Reuben a complimentary note, rare after a cattle call of 340 colleges. Later, she invited him to an all-expense-paid minority admissions weekend on campus.
Reuben did not think twice.

Gerta Xhelo
A New Future Versus an Attitude
Gerta was in the Grover Cleveland college office, Room 118A, on the day in April 2001 when seniors streamed in with their financial aid offers. Among these impoverished immigrant students, an invitation to their No. 1 school is meaningless unless somebody pays the bills. They don't choose a college. They choose a financial aid package. 
Yena Huang got into Middlebury, with grants of $27,690 and a $4,000 loan. That left her shy $2,610 of the full cost of $34,300. She also got into Cornell under a special program for disadvantaged students. It required she complete six weeks of remedial studies over the summer. But her education would be free. Choosing the free ride at Cornell was a no-brainer for Roz Sternlieb, the college counselor. It was exactly how she hoped to get Gerta into a college a year later. 
In many ways, Gerta Xhelo (pronounced JEL-o) was under the most intense pressure of the three students. Her parents, Zegir and Shpresa Xhelo, had given up successful careers in Albania four years ago to bring their children from the chaotic aftermath of Communism to America. Mr. Xhelo, 66, had been a Ph.D. economist, chief financial officer in the seaside city of Vlora, where the family lived. Mrs. Xhelo had been a laboratory technician.
In New York, Gerta's father stuffed circulars into plastic sacks, and had a second job as a building guard. Mrs. Xhelo, 52 and in poor health, had a seasonal job in a sweater factory, where she complained that "the managers have to count on their fingers."
Gerta's parents hounded her to study and set limits on television and boyfriends. Gerta is their future. Her future is college. 
Ms. Sternlieb began advising the junior class in the spring, calling the top 150 of 464 students, one by one, to her cramped cubicle. The office is a sanctuary. Outside the door, police officers break up fights in the noisy corridors. The bathrooms are locked and patrolled by monitors. The rules for when you can use them are so complicated they require a manual, Gerta said. 
Ms. Sternlieb must micromanage everything for immigrant teenagers like Gerta, seeing that each deadline is met and that no piece of paper leaves her office stained with soda. An intact loving family is a blessing. But the Xhelos and others like them are helpless during college admissions season because they speak no English and know nothing of the American education system. 
"They throw their trust here because they don't know," Ms. Sternlieb said. "I'm God to them."
Gerta, unlike many of the top immigrant students at Grover Cleveland -- the school's valedictorians and prizewinners -- wanted to be popular and veered between "the kids who are street-smart and the kids who are brain-smart." She missed appointments with Ms. Sternlieb and scholarship deadlines as often as she changed her hair color. 
The counselor had the sense to go slowly. She did not argue when Gerta said she had to go to school locally to look after her family, who "came all the way to America for me." She complimented her for moving from "English as a second language" classes in just over a year. She noted her Advanced Placement classes, her membership in the honor society and her class rank of 37. 
There was nothing exceptional in Gerta's file, no way to see her sophistication about world events, her keen sense of justice, her lively mind. Ms. Sternlieb was playing a hunch that this girl might stumble through high school, then find herself in college. 
Ms. Sternlieb was modest in her suggestions: Pace, St. John's, Fordham, SUNY and CUNY campuses. She knew the girl wanted New York University, mostly because of "Felicity" on television. It might be possible under the Higher Education Opportunity Program that got Yena Huang into Cornell.
"Is it for retards?" Gerta asked. Ms. Sternlieb would worry about her misguided objection later. 
Gerta had to jump through hoops unheard of at Collegiate. She would have to apply for fee waivers for SAT's, which cost $24, and college applications, which cost up to $75. She would later file a Fafsa, or Free Application for Federal Student Aid. And then there were scholarships, like those offered by the United Federation of Teachers or Coca-Cola -- each with its own set of essays.
Gerta hated essays.
"I'm the bum in the family," Gerta said in July from her regular perch on the living room couch. Her summer job search had led nowhere, so she watched soap operas, painted her nails, tried to ignore the weary faces of her parents and fretted about the fall. 
She had reason to worry. She had skipped the first session of an SAT class to go to New Jersey with her 20-year-old cousin, Eneida Licaj, and some Albanian friends, where they listened to Metallica and drank beer. She missed the second for a trip to Canada. 
Gerta insisted that Ms. Licaj was helping her study. But by August, work had stopped "because of the hot weather." Gerta knew the pretense was weak. "It seems like a good excuse, don't you think?" she said in an e-mail message. "Hahahahahaha!" 
The counselor, also on holiday, did not mask her concern over Gerta's wayward summer or her academic slide: a 91 average as a freshman, 86 as a sophomore and 78 as a junior. "This is a critical year," Ms. Sternlieb said. "It will make her or break her."
Gerta dreaded her first encounter of senior year with Ms. Sternlieb. "I know she's going to be really upset," the girl said. "I see her in that office nudging everybody. A lot of people in this school go to college because of her. They may not know that, but it's true." 
As September approached, the girl took stock. "I hung out with the wrong people," she confided. "They pulled me down to their level." Fall brought some changes in Gerta's approach to the college application process, but not a complete makeover.
Ms. Sternlieb begged seniors to keep all their college papers together. "I'm human, I could misplace something," she said. Gerta often couldn't find a form when Ms. Sternlieb needed it. But Ms. Sternlieb was patient. Maybe the girl was just a late starter.
Gerta's strengths became more apparent in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, which she watched from the upper floors of Grover Cleveland in Ridgewood, Queens, overlooking Lower Manhattan. She had a wide-ranging interest in world affairs, rare among self-absorbed adolescents. She spoke knowledgeably about Islam, earlier bombings of American embassies in Africa and the destroyer Cole. She visited ground zero, read the Albanian and Italian newspapers online and translated CNN each night for her parents.
She and Ms. Sternlieb began a debate about staying at home or going away to college that lasted from fall to spring. She could go to St. John's as a commuter, like Ms. Licaj, who lives with the Xhelos. Or she could commute to Pace and still be home at night. 
Throughout junior year, Gerta would not even consider going away. What about the day when her mother, who has a bad heart, struggled to breathe until her lips tinged blue? Gerta missed a math Regents exam to take her to the hospital. Or the times her younger brother's teachers came to her, not her parents, with reports the boy was not turning in his homework. 
But by senior year, Gerta felt torn between duty and desire. Every time she stopped in the college office, Ms. Sternlieb peppered the girl with stories about others before her who had resisted leaving home, changed their minds and thrived. 
Gerta's mother, alarmed if her children are 10 minutes late, turned her head away silently whenever her daughter broached the subject of going away. "Maybe she'll come around," Gerta said, unconvincingly.
Gerta's father, a worldly man whose relatives had been killed, jailed and persecuted by the Albanian Communists, was more open-minded. "For me, it's what's best for Gerta," he said. "She learns to take care of herself."
But Gerta had her doubts. During the summer, as she contemplated what lay ahead, she said: "This coming year is going to decide a lot of things in my life. If I want, I could screw it up real bad."
